column3: Sha’ar HaMayim HaKatzar, written by the Rashba (Shlomo ben Aderet 1235–1310), is an abridgment of Sha’ar HaMayim HaAroch which is a compilation of laws pertaining to the mikvah (ritual bath).

Tanna debei Eliyahu (Teachings of the School of Elijah) is the composite name of a midrash, consisting of two parts, whose final redaction took place at the end of the 10th century CE. The first part is called Seder Eliyahu Rabbah (31 chapters); the second, Seder Eliyahu Zuṭa (15 chapters). The underlying theme of the Tanna debe Eliyahu, which, with many interruptions, runs through the whole work, is the evolution of the world-system. The midrash calls the single periods of the history of man "shiṭṭot" (series). The first series, which deals with the beginning of the world and extends to the moment when man was driven out of Eden, consists of two subsections, (a) Ma'aseh Merkabah and (b) Ma'aseh Bereshit. The second series embraces the period from the expulsion of man from Eden to the Flood.  The six series of the world-system, found in the first part of the book was conceived prior to the creation of mankind. In the second part of the book mankind’s immorality seem it sink lower and lower until finally its destruction became necessary.
Tikkunei Zohar is a major Kabbalistic text. Written mostly in Aramaic, it is a collection of seventy commentaries on the the first word of the Torah, "Bereishit".

Zohar Chadash is a collection of manuscripts that were found containing material pertaining to the Zohar but not included in printed editions of the work. The manuscripts were later organized, mostly by Torah portion, and printed as their own work.

column1: Letter from Ramban to his son
column3: Iggeret HaRamban is a letter from the Ramban (Rabbi Moses ben Nahman 1194–1270) to his son explicating the ethical rules which guide his life and instructing him and the future generations to follow his ways.
column4: מכתב שכולל הרבה עניני מוסר, שכתב הרמב"ן ושלח לבנו ששהה באותו עת בקטולניא.

column3: Hilchot HaRif or Sefer HaHalachot, written by Isaac ben Jacob Alfasi ha-Cohen (1013–1103) compiles the legal decisions from the tractates of the Talmud relating to halakha that was practiced in his day. The Rif recorded the halakhic rulings without the discussions surrounding them. He also excluded all non-halakhic material. The Rif became the basis of many later works.
column4: הלכות הריף או "ספר ההלכות", שנכתב על ידי יצחק בן יעקב אלפסי הכהן (1013-1103), מסכם את ההכרעות הנוגעות להלכה במסכתות התלמוד ללא הדיונים ומשא ומתן הארוך.

column3: Written by the Rashba (Rabbi Shlomo ben Avraham ibn Aderet), Torat HaBayit HaAroch is a compendium of laws related to the home, including kashrut laws. The abridged version is called Torat HaBayit HaKatzar.

Hilchot HaRif or Sefer HaHalachot, written by Isaac ben Jacob Alfasi ha-Cohen (1013–1103) compiles the legal decisions from the tractates of the Talmud relating to halakha that was practiced in his day. The Rif recorded the halakhic rulings without the discussions surrounding them. He also excluded all non-halakhic material. The Rif became the basis of many later works.
column4: הלכות הריף או "ספר ההלכות", שנכתב על ידי יצחק בן יעקב אלפסי הכהן (1013-1103), מסכם את ההכרעות הנוגעות להלכה במסכתות התלמוד ללא הדיונים ומשא ומתן הארוך.

column3: Commentary on the Talmud written by Rabbi Shmuel Eliezer Edels (Maharsha). Maharsha was an important halakhic authority in Poland (1555 – 1631). His commentary elucidates comments of Rashi and the Tosefists.
column4: פירוש על חלק ההלכה של גמרא, רש"י, ותוספות שבתלמוד בבלי.

column7: Spain; Fes, Morocco; Acre, Israel; Fustat, Egypt

column3: Hilchot HaRif or Sefer HaHalachot, written by Isaac ben Jacob Alfasi ha-Cohen (1013–1103) compiles the legal decisions from the tractates of the Talmud relating to halakha that was practiced in his day. The Rif recorded the halakhic rulings without the discussions surrounding them. He also excluded all non-halakhic material. The Rif became the basis of many later works.

column3: Written by the Rashba (Rabbi Shlomo ben Avraham ibn Aderet), Torat HaBayit HaKatzar is an abridged version of the author’s Torat HaBayit HaAroch. The work is a compendium of laws related to the home, including kashrut laws. Torat HaBayit HaKatzar concentrates on the practical halakhic decisions and puts less emphasis on the discussions surrounding the halakha.
Written by Shlomo ben Avraham ibn Aderet, Avodat HaKodesh is a compendium of laws relating to Shabbat and the Jewish holidays.

Rambam’s Introduction to the Mishnah is a survey of the chronology of the Oral Law and sets forth the basic principles of Jewish law. Although the text was written as an introduction to the Mishnah, it actually stands alone and was printed as its own work.
column7: Spain; Fes, Morocco; Acre, Israel; Fustat, Egypt

column3: A moving prayer, describing the awe of the Day of Judgement, that is recited on the High Holy Days before Kedusha of Mussaf. According to a tradition cited in Sefer Ohr Zarua, R' Ephraim of Bonn attributed it to an 11th century German sage by the name of R' Amnon of Mainz (Mayence), who composed it after sanctifying G-d's name by rejecting a demand by the local bishop that he convert to Christianity. However, modern scholars believe that it is of much earlier composition, being that fragments of the prayer were found in the Cairo Geniza dating to the 8th Century. Some researchers believe that it was composed by Yannai in the sixth century
column4: פיוט מרגש המתאר את אימת יום הדין הנאמר בראש השנה ויום הכיפורים לפני הקדושה בתפילת מוסף. על פי מסורת שהובאה בספר אור-זרוע, ר' אפרים מבונא מיחס אותה לחכם גרמני מהמאה ה -11 בשם ר' אמנון ממגנצא (מיינץ), שחיבר אותה לאחר שקידש שם שמים על ידי שדחה דרישת הבישוף המקומי שהוא יתנצר. עם זאת, חוקרים מודרניים מאמינים כי הוא חובר הרבה קודם לכן, כי חלקים של התפילה נמצאו בגניזת קהיר של המאה ה-8. כמה חוקרים סוברים שחובר על ידי הפייטן ינאי במאה השישית.

column3: Hilchot HaRif or Sefer HaHalachot, written by Isaac ben Jacob Alfasi ha-Cohen (1013–1103) compiles the legal decisions from the tractates of the Talmud relating to halakha that was practiced in his day. column1: Bedek HaBayit on Torat HaBayit HaAroch
column3: Written by Rabbi Aharon Halevi (Ra’ah), Bedek HaBayit on Torat HaBayit HaAroch is a criticism of the Rashba’s work. The Rashba answered the critique in his book Mishmeret HaBayit.

Written by Rabbi Shmuel Eliezer Edels, the Maharsha (1555 – 1631, Poland), Chidushei Aggadot is a commentary on the aggadic (non-legal) portions of the Talmud. The commentary reflects the author’s vast knowledge of philosophy and Kabbalah.

Written by Naftali Zvi Yehuda Berlin (1816-1893), also known as the Netziv, Haamek Davar is a commentary on the Torah. The commentary is mostly based on the Netziv’s Parashat Hashavua shiur in the Volozhin Yeshiva.
column4: נכתב על ידי ר' נפתלי צבי יהודה ברלין (1816-1893), הידוע גם בשם "הנצי"ב". "העמק דבר" הוא פירוש על התורה, המבוסס בעיקר על שיעורים בפרשת השבוע שמסר הנצי"ב בישיבת וולוז'ין.

column3: A compendium of the laws of scribal writing, by the author of "Kitzur Shulchan Arukh".
column4: הלכות ספרות (כתיבת ספר תורה, תפלין ומזוזות) מבעל ה"קיצור שלחן ערוך".

column1: Kessef Mishneh on Mishneh Torah, Admission into the Sanctuary
column3: Kessef Mishneh is a commentary on Rambam’s Mishneh Torah, written by Joseph Karo, and published during his lifetime. In the introduction to this work, the author writes that his goal was to cite the source of each law, and to defend the Rambam from Raavad's arguments.
column4: כסף משנה הוא פירוש למשנה תורה של הרמב"ם, שנכתב על ידי ר' יוסף קארו, ונדפס בחייו בוונציה, 1574-1575. בהקדמתו כותב המחבר שמטרות הספר הן לציין את מקורותיו של הרמב"ם בכל הלכה, ולהשיב לראב"ד ולרמ"ך בהשגותיהם על רמב"ם.

column1: Kessef Mishneh on Mishneh Torah, Defilement by a Corpse
column3: Kessef Mishneh is a commentary on Rambam’s Mishneh Torah, written by Joseph Karo, and published during his lifetime. In the introduction to this work, the author writes that his goal was to cite the source of each law, and to defend the Rambam from Raavad's arguments.
column4: כסף משנה הוא פירוש למשנה תורה של הרמב"ם, שנכתב על ידי ר' יוסף קארו, ונדפס בחייו בוונציה, 1574-1575. בהקדמתו כותב המחבר שמטרות הספר הן לציין את מקורותיו של הרמב"ם בכל הלכה, ולהשיב לראב"ד ולרמ"ך בהשגותיהם על רמב"ם.

column4: כסף משנה הוא פירוש למשנה תורה של הרמב"ם, שנכתב על ידי ר' יוסף קארו, ונדפס בחייו בוונציה, 1574-1575. בהקדמתו כותב המחבר שמטרות הספר הן לציין את מקורותיו של הרמב"ם בכל הלכה, ולהשיב לראב"ד ולרמ"ך בהשגותיהם על רמב"ם.

column4: כסף משנה הוא פירוש למשנה תורה של הרמב"ם, שנכתב על ידי ר' יוסף קארו, ונדפס בחייו בוונציה, 1574-1575. בהקדמתו כותב המחבר שמטרות הספר הן לציין את מקורותיו של הרמב"ם בכל הלכה, ולהשיב לראב"ד ולרמ"ך בהשגותיהם על רמב"ם.

column1: Mishmeret HaBayit on Torat HaBayit HaAroch
column3: Mishmeret HaBayit is the Rashba’s response to Ra’ah’s critique of his work, Torat HaBayit HaKatzar. Ra’ah’s critique is called Bedek HaBayit.

Rambam’s Introduction to the Mishnah is a survey of the chronology of the Oral Law and sets forth the basic principles of Jewish law. Although the text was written as an introduction to the Mishnah, it actually stands alone and was printed as its own work.
column7: Spain; Fes, Morocco; Acre, Israel; Fustat, Egypt

column3: Sha’ar HaMayim HaAroch, written by the Rashba (Shlomo ben Aderet 1235–1310), is a compilation of laws pertaining to the mikvah (ritual bath).

column1: Tosafot Yom Tov on Mishnah Arakhin
column3: Commentary on the Mishnah written by Rabbi Yom-Tov Lipmann Heller (1579 - 1654). Tosafot Yom Tov has become a standard commentary on the Mishnah and complements the Bartenura commentary.The release and digitization of this work was kindly sponsored by Nicole and Raanan Agus.
column4: פירוש המשנה לר' יום טוב ליפמן הלר, המהווה כעין השלמה לפירוש הברטנורא. הוא נדפס, (או קיצורו הנקרא "עיקר תוספות יום טוב"), ברוב המהדורות של המשנה ליד פירושו של ברטנורא.

column4: פירוש המשנה לר' יום טוב ליפמן הלר, המהווה כעין השלמה לפירוש הברטנורא. הוא נדפס, (או קיצורו הנקרא "עיקר תוספות יום טוב"), ברוב המהדורות של המשנה ליד פירושו של ברטנורא.

column3: Written by Rabbi Shmuel Eliezer Edels, the Maharsha (1555 – 1631, Poland), Chidushei Aggadot is a commentary on the aggadic (non-legal) portions of the Talmud. The commentary reflects the author’s vast knowledge of philosophy and Kabbalah.
column4: פירוש על כל האגדות שבתלמוד בבלי.

column3: Commentary by Gershom ben Yehudah (Mainz, c. 960 - c.1028). Rabbeinu Gershom is best known for his takkanot, ordinances, banning polygamy, requiring both parties to agree to a divorce, and forbidding people to remind those who were forced to convert to Christianity of their conversions.

Commentary on the Talmud written by the Rashba, Rabbi Shlomo ben Avraham ibn Aderet (1235–1310). Rashba was a student of Ramban and follows his methodology. Rashba’s commentary is characterized by the depth of analysis and his search for the pshat (contextual meaning) of the text. Rashba’s commentary includes definitive legal rulings.

column1: Abraham Cohen Footnotes to the English Translation of Masechet Berakhot
column3: Footnotes to the Soncino translation of the first tractate of the Talumud.

column1: Be'er Mayim Chaim on Chofetz Chaim
column3: Footnotes to the Sefer Chafetz Chaim, containing sources and further analysis to the main body of text, "Mekor Chaim".
column4: מראי מקומות והערות לחלק ההלכה של הספר חפץ חיים, הנקרא על ידי המחבר "מקור חיים".

column3: Commentary on the Talmud written by Rabbi Joshua Kulp, Rosh Yeshiva at the Conservative Yeshiva in Jerusalem. Rabbi Kulp’s English commentary is accessible to beginner learners and does not assume previous Talmud experience.

A collection of Responsa written by David ben Solomon ibn Zimra (Radbaz). The Radbaz (c. 1479 - 1517) was an important halakhic decisor who lived in Spain, Cairo, Fes, Jerusalem, and Tzfat.

A commentary on the Talmud written by Rabbi Meir ben Jacob Ha-Kohen Schiff. Rabbi Schiff (1608 - c. 1644) wrote commentary on the entire Talmud although only a portion remains extant. A defining characteristic of Rabbi Schiff's commentary is his dislike of pilpul.

Pirke de-Rabbi Eliezer (Chapters of Rabbi Eliezer) is an aggadic-midrashic work on the Torah containing exegesis and retellings of biblical stories. The composition enjoyed widespread circulation and recognition throughout Jewish history, and continues to do so in the present. Traditionally, it has been understood to be a tannaitic composition which originated with the tanna Rabbi Eliezer ben Hyrcanus, - a disciple of Rabbi Yohanan ben Zakai and teacher of Rabbi Akiva - and his disciples. However, modern scholarship has shown the book in fact a a medieval work from the 8th Century. The work is divided into 54 chapters, which may be divided into seven groups. Pirke De-Rabbi Eliezer comprises exegesis, legends and folklore, as well as astronomical discussions related to the story of the Creation. The author dwells longest on the description of the second day of Creation, in which the Ma'aseh ha-Merkavah (Ezek. i.) is described in various forms.

column3: Commentary on the Talmud written by the Rashba, Rabbi Shlomo ben Avraham ibn Aderet (1235–1310). Rashba was a student of Ramban and follows his methodology. Rashba’s commentary is characterized by the depth of analysis and his search for the pshat (contextual meaning) of the text. Rashba’s commentary includes definitive legal rulings.

Hilchot HaRif or Sefer HaHalachot, written by Isaac ben Jacob Alfasi ha-Cohen (1013–1103) compiles the legal decisions from the tractates of the Talmud relating to halakha that was practiced in his day. The Rif recorded the halakhic rulings without the discussions surrounding them. He also excluded all non-halakhic material. The Rif became the basis of many later works.
column4: הלכות הריף או "ספר ההלכות", שנכתב על ידי יצחק בן יעקב אלפסי הכהן (1013-1103), מסכם את ההכרעות הנוגעות להלכה במסכתות התלמוד ללא הדיונים ומשא ומתן הארוך.

column3: Talmud commentary written by the the Rosh, Rabbi Asher ben Yehiel, a German and Spanish halakhic authority (c. 1250 - 1327). Having been a leader in both Germany and Spain, the Rosh was familiar with the leading halakhic authorities of both countries and included teachings from both. The Rosh’s commentary displays his independence of judgement as he states his legal opinion according to what he views as most sound, even if it goes against other respected authorities.

column3: A famous collection of Rabbi Mordekhai Leiner's thoughts and sermons on the weekly parsha, on holidays and on various other texts, they were gathered by his grandson. Some of the unconventional observations about personal struggle and the practice of halakha in this book have elicited renewed interest in the last several decades.

Mekhilta de-Rabbi Ishmael (Measure, Rule of R. Ishmael) is a halakhic midrash to the Book of Exodus, used to denote a compilation of Scriptural exegesis using Talmudic hermeneutics. Neither the Babylonian nor the Jerusalem Talmud mention the Mekhilta by name, but it is referred to once as She'ar Sifre debe Rab. The first person to mention the Mekhilta by name was the author of the Geonic work Halakhot Gedolot. Another Geonic name for it was Mekhilta de-Erez Yisrael. The author, or more correctly the redactor, of the Mekhilta cannot be ascertained. Some scholars thought it was R. Ishmael ben Elisha, R. Akiba's contemporary. The present Mekhilta cannot, however, be the one composed by R. Ishmael, as is proved by the references in it to R. Ishmael's pupils and to other later tannaim. Both Maimonides and the author of the Halakhot Gedolot, moreover, refer, evidently on the basis of a tradition, to a much larger Mekhilta extending to the end of the Torah, while the midrash here considered discusses only certain passages of Exodus. It must be assumed, therefore, that R. Ishmael composed an explanatory midrash to the last four books of the Torah, and that his pupils amplified it.

One of two classic commentaries on the Tur by Rabbi Joshua Falk, the Prisha is made up of explanation of the legal decisions of the Tur.

Rabbi Moshe ben Maimon’s (Rambam) commentary was the first to be written on the entire Mishnah. The commentary was written by Rambam in Judeo-Arabic, and has been translated into Hebrew. He started working on it at age 23 while living in Spain, and completed it seven years later after settling in Egypt. It offers a running commentary on the Mishnah, and often includes a Halachic ruling based on the Talmud's conclusion.
column4: פירושו של הרמב"ם הוא הראשון שנכתב על כל המשנה, והוא אחד הפירושים החשובים שעל המשנה. הרמב"ם כתבו בצעירותו בשפה הערבית-יהודית, ותורגם פעמים רבות לעברית. הפירוש מכיל ביאור קצר לכל משנה ודיון מעמיק בעניינים המרכזיים שבה. בסוף כל עניין הוא פוסק הלכה על-פי מסקנת התלמוד.

A summary of the commandments, based on the traditional count of 613. It includes a discussion of how Rambam decided which commandments should be included. This section, as well as the body of the work, inspired much discussion, including the glosses of Ramban.

Commentary written by R. Samuel David Luzzatto, Shadal, (Italy 1800 – 1865). Shadal’s commentary develops a unique approach to resolving the problem that occurs when the pshat (contextual) meaning of the text conflicts with halakha, as presented in midrash halakha. Shadal argues that the pshat reflects what the Torah means and the midrash reflects the halakha and not biblical interpretation. He claims that instead of being biblical interpretation, the midrash halakha is rabbinic legislation with the desire to take a more lenient position than the Torah text.

Biography of R' Nachman of Breslov, written by his student, R' Natan.
column4: תולדות ר' נחמן מברסלב, נכתב על ידי תלמידו ר' נתן.

column3: An introduction to the thought of Rebbe Nachman of Breslov, compiled by his closest disciple, Rabbi Natan of Nemirov.
The prayer book according to the Ashkenazi rite.

Sifrei (Books) also known as Sifrei debe Rav or Sifrei Rabbah refers to either of two works of Midrash halakhah, based on the biblical books of Bemidbar (Numbers) and Devarim (Deuteronomy). The earliest Sifrei is found in Talmudic times and successively cited by Geonim and Rishonim. This early version is certainly not identical with the modern Sifrei. The modern Sifrei is not a uniform work, but one composed of two parts, one on Numbers and one on Deuteronomy that were joined together. The Sifrei to Numbers is evidently a midrash which originated in R. Ishmael's school, and which has all the peculiarities and characteristics of such a work though this does not exclude borrowing form Mekhilta de R. Shimon. The Sifrei to Deuteronomy is of an entirely different nature. The main portion (Nos. 53-303), halakhic in character, is preceded and followed by haggadic parts, and it has all the characteristics of a midrash from the school of R. Akiba. Several anonymous passages may be cited to express the views of R. Simeon; this midrash may with a fair degree of certainty be ascribed to him. The editor certainly drew upon other midrashic works besides R. Simeon's midrash, especially upon that of R. Ishmael.
Allegoric tales recounted by R' Nachman of Breslov and recorded by his disciple, R' Natan.
column4: מעשיות בדרך משל שסיפר ר' נחמן מברסלב לתלמידו ר' נתן, שרשם אותם והוציאם לאור.

column3: A voluminous collection of responsa by one of North Africa's most important rabbis, the author writes that he never had cause to retract a single one of them.
A three-volume work of responsa.
Many of these responsa were originally written in Arabic, and a large portion deal with questions about the proper understanding of various passages in the Talmud.
Responsa written by the Rosh, Rabbi Asher ben Yehiel (c. 1250 - 1327). The questions were arranged into different categories by one of his students.
Responsa written by the Rosh, Rabbi Asher ben Yehiel (c. 1250 - 1327).The questions were arranged into different categories by one of his students.
Responsa written by the Rosh, Rabbi Asher ben Yehiel (c. 1250 - 1327). The questions were arranged into different categories by one of his students.

A collection of responsa written by the medieval rabbi, halakhic authority and Talmudist, Shlomo ben Avraham ibn Aderet (Rashba). The Rashba (1235–1310) lived in Spain, where he was a leader of the community. He was a student of the Ramban.
Commentary on Piskei HaRosh, written by Rabbi Aaron Samuel Kaidanover (Poland-Lithuania, 1614-1676).
column4: פירוש על פסקי הרא"ש, חיבר הרב אהרן שמואל קאיידנובר.

column3: One of the classic Rishonim (midieval scholars) on certain tractates.
A Halachic work written in the era of the Rishonim of unknown authorship. Some say it is an abridgement or an earlier draft of Orchot Chaim.
column4: ספר הלכה מתקופת הראשונים המכיל דינים ומנהגים לכל השנה. שם המחבר אינו ידוע, ויש משערים שהוא מהדורא ראשונית או קיצור של הספר "ארחות חיים" של ר' אהרן מלוניל.

column3: Responsa consisting of Halakhic inquiries received by the members of Kollel Eretz Chemda from rabbis in Jewish communities around the world. These fascinating responsa, many of which deal with our developing modern world, have been collected in a series of books entitled "B'Mareh HaBazak".
column4: תשובות לשאלות מרבני הגולה. השאלות מבטאות את המצב מיוחד של קהילות ישראל בכל קצוות תבל בימינו אנו. התשובות מתמודדות עם המציאות בעולם מודרני מתפתח בדרך של "דרכיה דרכי נעם". הספרים עוסקים בארבעת חלקי ה"שלחן ערוך" תוך ניסיון לקחת בחשבון גם את החלק החמישי ההופך את התורה ל"תורת חיים".

column3: Beit Yosef, by Rabbi Joseph Caro, is a long, detailed commentary on the Arba'ah Turim. ‎It ‎served as a precursor to the Shulhan Arukh, which Rabbi Caro wrote later in his life. Karo began ‎the ‎Beth Yosef in 1522 at Adrianople, finished it in 1542 at Safed in the Land of Israel; he published ‎it in ‎‎1550–59. This work analyzes the theories and conclusions of the Tur and opinions of authorities ‎not ‎mentioned by the latter. Karo evidences not only an astonishing range of reading, covering ‎almost ‎the entire rabbinic literature up to his time, but also remarkable powers of critical ‎investigation. He ‎evidences no inclination to simply accept the opinions of ancient authorities, ‎notwithstanding his ‎great respect for them.‎ Despite Caro's own preference for the Beit Yosef, it ‎was his shorter work Shulhan Arukh, which he wrote for students and ignorami that became ‎authoritative.‎
Maharal's supercommentary to Rashi's Torah commentary.
column4: פירושו של המהר"ל מפראג לפירוש רש"י על התורה.

column3: Maharal's supercommentary to Rashi's Torah commentary.
column4: פירושו של המהר"ל מפראג לפירוש רש"י על התורה.

column3: Technical notes about wording and textual variants serving as background to the translation choices made in this classic Jewish translation of the entire Bible into English.
Teachings of the Maggid of Mezeritch, compiled by his students. (The last letters of the three words in the title spell the Maggid's name "Dov").
column4: ליקוט של תורות מהמגיד ממעזריטש, נערך על ידי תלמידיו. (סופי תיבות של שם הספר הם אותיות "דוב".)

column3: Encyclopedic work listing the various Midrashim, with a description of each. The full text of some of the shorter Midrashim is included.
column4: אנצילופדיה למדרשים, כולל טקסט של המדרשים היותר קטנים.

column3: A commentary by the author of Shaarei Teshuvah focusing on the ethical and religious teachings learned from Pirkei Avot.

A collection of legends about the Baal Shem Tov, founder of Chasidism, written by Dov ben Samuel Baer, a son-in-law of the Besht's secretary.  The book exists in two different versions: the Kopys edition (1815), and the Berdychiv edition of the same year. The latter omits many legends which are found in the former, especially those that are of a particularly extraordinary nature. Later editions, of which there are more than ten, follow either of these editions, and some are combinations of the two.
column4: קובץ של כמאתיים וחמישים סיפורים מחייו ופועלו של מייסד תנועת החסידות, ר' ישראל בעל שם טוב, נכתב על ידי דוב בער בן שמואל שהיה חתנו של מזכירו (כותב קמיעות ועוזרו האישי) של הבעל שם טוב.

column3: Tosafot that were not included by the editing process of the Tosafot that are generally studied with the Talmud. In today's editions of the Talmud, many of these statements appear in the margins in smaller letters.

Halakhic code considered to be one of the primary sources of Jewish law after the Talmud. The work consists of four sections: 1. Orach Chaim addresses prayer, the Sabbath and festivals, and general daily religious duties. 2. Yoreh Deah deals with kashrut and laws related to family purity.  3. Even HaEzer deals with the laws of marriage and divorce. 4. Choshen Mishpat deals with civil law and business dealings.
Although the title of this book is literally translated as "Testament of R' Yisrael Baal Shem", it is actually a collection of the Baal Shem Tov's teachings that was compiled by his disciple.
column4: בניגוד למשתמע משם הספר, אין זה צוואתו של הבעש"ט וגם לא נכתב על ידו, אלא הוא ליקוט של אמרות, הוראות והנהגות מהבעש"ט ומתלמידו, הרב המגיד.

column1: Ba'er Hetev on Shulchan Arukh, Choshen Mishpat
column3: A short summary of the major commentaries and relevant responsa on the various parts of the Shulchan Arukh.

column3: A short summary of the major commentaries and relevant responsa on the various parts of the Shulchan Arukh.

Rama's commentary on Tur, originally written in greatly expanded form, was subsequently shortened when the author became aware that Beit Yosef had completed a similar work. Rama then condensed his work and included only the material which complements Beit Yosef's work. The text of Darchei Moshe which is printed together with Tur is a further abridged version, with the complete version printed separately in the back of many editions of Tur.
column4: פירוש הרמ"א לטור, בתחילה נכתב מבלי לדעת שגם ר' יוסף קארו עובד על משהו דומה, וכשהשלים החלק על אורח חיים נודע לו שכבר יצא לאור הספר "בית יוסף", ולכן הוא קיצר את ספרו ועשהו מעין השלמה על ה"בית יוסף". ה"דרכי משה" שנדפס בדפי הטור הוא גם מקוצר ממה שהוציא המחבר, והפירוש השלם נדפס בסוף הכרך בפני עצמו ברוב מהדורות הטור.

column1: Footnotes to Teshuvot haRashba part IV
Footnotes to Teshuvot haRashba part V
Footnotes to Teshuvot haRashba part VI
Footnotes to Teshuvot haRashba part VII

column3: Teachings of the Baal Shem Tov on the parsha.
An anonymous commentary on Tractate Tamid printed in the Vilna edition in place of Rashi.
column4: פירוש למסכת תמיד שנדפס בדפוס וילנא במקום רש"י.

column3: Sefer Mitzvot Gadol (Semag) is a book of halakhot organized, in general, according to Rambam’s listing of the 613 mitzvot. The book is separated into two parts: Section 1 on positive commandments and Section 2 on negative commandments. The author cites the Biblical verse, rabbinic exegesis, relevant Talmudic sources and comments by other halakhic authorities for each mitzvah. A table of contents for each book, called "Remazim", helps the user to find a specific mitzvah. In the era preceding the publication of the Shulchan Aruch, Semag was the principal halachic text studied in Ashkenazic academies.

A collection of responsa written by the medieval rabbi, halakhic authority and Talmudist, Shlomo ben Avraham ibn Aderet (Rashba). The Rashba (1235–1310) lived in Spain, where he was a leader of the community. He was a student of the Ramban.

column1: Tosafot Yom Tov on Mishnah Beitzah
column3: Commentary on the Mishnah written by Rabbi Yom-Tov Lipmann Heller (1579 - 1654). Tosafot Yom Tov has become a standard commentary on the Mishnah and complements the Bartenura commentary.The release and digitization of this work was kindly sponsored by Nicole and Raanan Agus.
column4: פירוש המשנה לר' יום טוב ליפמן הלר, המהווה כעין השלמה לפירוש הברטנורא. הוא נדפס, (או קיצורו הנקרא "עיקר תוספות יום טוב"), ברוב המהדורות של המשנה ליד פירושו של ברטנורא.

column4: פירוש המשנה לר' יום טוב ליפמן הלר, המהווה כעין השלמה לפירוש הברטנורא. הוא נדפס, (או קיצורו הנקרא "עיקר תוספות יום טוב"), ברוב המהדורות של המשנה ליד פירושו של ברטנורא.

column1: Vilna Gaon's students letter to the Lost Tribes of Israel
column3: A letter sent from the Ashkenazi communities of Safed and Jerusalem to the lost tribes that they had hoped would be found by an emissary sent to Yemen in 1830. The letter informs the lost tribes of the contemporary circumstances of world Jewry, and brings them up to date about the development of Jewish law.
One of the classic commentaries on Tractate Sanhedrin from the epoch of the Rishonim

Responsa consisting of Halakhic inquiries received by the members of Kollel Eretz Chemda from rabbis in Jewish communities around the world. These fascinating responsa, many of which deal with our developing modern world, have been collected in a series of books entitled "B'Mareh HaBazak".
column4: תשובות לשאלות מרבני הגולה. השאלות מבטאות את המצב מיוחד של קהילות ישראל בכל קצוות תבל בימינו אנו. התשובות מתמודדות עם המציאות בעולם מודרני מתפתח בדרך של "דרכיה דרכי נעם". הספרים עוסקים בארבעת חלקי ה"שלחן ערוך" תוך ניסיון לקחת בחשבון גם את החלק החמישי ההופך את התורה ל"תורת חיים".

column2: Aaron Ben Asher Perlow of Karlin
column3: The bulk of this work contains the teachings of Aaron of Karlin II, but also included are extant writings of his grandfather, Aaron HaGadol of Karlin I, his father - Asher I, and son - Asher II. The content of the book includes insights on the weekly Torah portion and Jewish holidays, Chasidic aphorisms, and letters from the author to his son and to his followers. Also included are rules of daily conduct according to Chasidic practice.
column4: רובו של הספר הם תורות של ר' אהרן מקרלין (השני) לפרשת השבוע וחגים, אמרות חסידיות מלוקטות בשמו, ואגרות ששלח לחסידיו ולבנו. אך נוספו בו גם ליקוטים מכתבי זקנו ר' אהרן הגדול, אביו ר' אשר הראשון, ובנו ר' אשר השני. בראש הספר ובסופו מופיעים הנהגות שונות שכתבו אדמור"י קרלין לתלמידיהם.

column3: An independent and original commentary on the Torah focused on the simple understanding  (peshat) by one of the Tosafist masters. This work would become influential among subsequent Ashkenazi commentators, such as Chizukuni.

Written by Rabbi Israel Lipschitz (1782–1860), Tiferes Yisrael, often referred to as Mishnayos Yachin uBoaz is a commentary on the Mishnah. The commentary is divided into two parts; Yachin and Boaz. Yachin is the plain-sense explanation of the text, and Boaz contains lengthier analytical insights. Appended to each chapter is a section called "Hilchata Gevirta" containing a Halachic synopsis of each mishna. Many tractates are also preceded with an introduction and a separate essay discussing the subject matter at length.
column4: פירוש המשנה לרב ישראל ליפשיץ, נקרא גם "יכין ובועז" על שם שהוא נחלק לשני חלקים: "יכין" הוא ביאור פשט הפשוט של המשנה, ו"בועז" הוא חלק החידושים. בסוף כל פרק יש "הלכתא גבירתא" שהוא סיכום הלכתי של כל משנה. גם הוסיף הקדמות לכל הסדרים, ולהרבה מסכתות יש מאמר ארוך העוסק בענינים הנדונים בהם.

Appended to each chapter is a section called "Hilchata Gevirta" containing a Halachic synopsis of each mishna. Many tractates are also preceded with an introduction and a separate essay discussing the subject matter at length.
column4: פירוש המשנה לרב ישראל ליפשיץ, נקרא גם "יכין ובועז" על שם שהוא נחלק לשני חלקים: "יכין" הוא ביאור פשט הפשוט של המשנה, ו"בועז" הוא חלק החידושים. בסוף כל פרק יש "הלכתא גבירתא" שהוא סיכום הלכתי של כל משנה. גם הוסיף הקדמות לכל הסדרים, ולהרבה מסכתות יש מאמר ארוך העוסק בענינים הנדונים בהם.

The commentary is divided into two parts; Yachin and Boaz. Yachin is the plain-sense explanation of the text, and Boaz contains lengthier analytical insights. Appended to each chapter is a section called "Hilchata Gevirta" containing a Halachic synopsis of each mishna. Many tractates are also preceded with an introduction and a separate essay discussing the subject matter at length.

column3: A work explaining various kabbalistic ideas, published posthumously.

Chiddushei Ramban are Ramban’s glosses on the Talmud. Ramban (1194–1270) was considered a great scholar at a young age. His commentary on the Talmud reflects his depth of knowledge and his deep respect for the legal authorities that came before him.

Written by Rabbi Shmuel Eliezer Edels, the Maharsha (1555 – 1631, Poland), Chidushei Aggadot is a commentary on the aggadic (non-legal) portions of the Talmud. The commentary reflects the author’s vast knowledge of philosophy and Kabbalah.

column1: Commentary on Sefer Hamitzvot of Rasag
column3: Comprehensive commentary on Sefer HaMitzvot of R' Saadia Gaon.
column4: ביאור רחב על ספר המצוות לרס"ג.

column3: Commentary on the Talmud written by Rabbi Joshua Kulp, Rosh Yeshiva at the Conservative Yeshiva in Jerusalem. Rabbi Kulp’s English commentary is accessible to beginner learners and does not assume previous Talmud experience.
Ramban's classic monograph about indirect damages, as culled from the various sources in the Talmud.
A hassidic commentary on the Torah from the Seer (Hozeh) of Lublin.

One of the classic works of Jewish ethics, the author begins with the question of belief. Along with duties of the heart related to ethics, Ibn Pekuda also sees belief in God and understanding His nature as obligations of the heart which a Jew must actively pursue.

A comprehensive history of the composition of the Mishnah and Talmud, which was written in response to an inquiry from the Jewish community of Kairouan, Tunisia. Several versions of this letter exist, two of which are presented here.
column4: איגרת המתאר בהרחבה השתלשלות התורה שבע"פ וסדר דורות המסורת, שנכתב כתשובה לחכמי קהילת קירואן בתוניסיה. יש כמה נוסחאות של האיגרת, שתים מהם מופיעים פה.

column3: Classic philosophical work which contains ten treatises discussing the basic foundations of Jewish belief.
column4: עשרה מאמרים על יסודי האמונה והתורה

column1: HaGra on Sefer Yetzirah Gra Version

column3: An ethical will the author sent to his family as he was departing upon his attempt to move to the Land of Israel.
Responsa attributed to Rashi.
column4: שו"ת מיוחסות לרש"י

column1: Kessef Mishneh on Mishneh Torah, Things Forbidden on the Altar
column3: Kessef Mishneh is a commentary on Rambam’s Mishneh Torah, written by Joseph Karo, and published during his lifetime. In the introduction to this work, the author writes that his goal was to cite the source of each law, and to defend the Rambam from Raavad's arguments.

Given first as an address at Yeshiva University in NY on the occasion of Israel’s Independence Day (Yom HaAtzmaut 1956), Kol Dodi Dofek discusses God and the Holocaust, the importance of the modern State of Israel and the role of Zionism in American Orthodoxy. Kol Dodi Dofek has become a classic text of religious Zionist philosophy.
Commentary of R' Yaakov Emden on Pirkei Avot.
column4: ביאור לר' יעקב עמדין על פרקי אבות.

column3: Commentary on Rambam's Sefer HaMitzvot. (The title of this work is a hint to the author's name "Aligri", which is Italian for 'glad of heart'.)
column4: ביאור לספר המצוות להרמב"ם. (שם הספר "לב שמח" הוא רמז לשם המחבר "אליגרי", שכך משמעותו באיטלקית.)

column3: Written by Rabbi Meir Leibush ben Yehiel Michel Wisser (Malbim), a trademark of the his commentary is his belief that there are no synonyms or repetition in the Tanakh. Each word represents a different idea or concept. Another important facet is his interest in connecting the written word to its rabbinic interpretation.
column4: פירוש פופולרי על תנ"ך של ר' מאיר לייבוש בן יחיאל מיכל ויסר (מלבי"ם). בפירושו לחומש הוא מביא את מדרשי ההלכה ודן בהם בהשוואה לפשט הפסוקים תוך דיוקים בדקדוק המקרא. המלבי"ם נודע בדרך ייחודית בפירושו למקרא, ולשיטתו אין שום חזרה וכפילות בפסוקים ('מילים נרדפות' כפי שכונה על ידי מפרשים אחרים), אלא כל מילה מייצגת מושג או רעיון אחר.

column3: Written by Rabbi Meir Leibush ben Yehiel Michel Wisser (Malbim), a trademark of the his commentary is his belief that there are no synonyms or repetition in the Tanakh. column3: Collection of sermons delivered by R' Kook in the years 1893 - 1896, while serving as rabbi in Zeimelis, Lithuania. It was printed from the manuscript by Mossad Merkaz Harav in 1999.
column4: דרשות של הרב הרב אברהם יצחק הכהן קוק בתקופת היותו הרב של העיירה זוימל בליטא. שמו של הספר רומז על שם המחבר: שׁוּר פירושו הַבֵּט, וזה גם פירוש המילה קוּק ביידיש, וכן חתם המחבר שמו בדף השער של הספר: "שור המכונה קוק".

column3: Written by Yosef Babad (1800–1874), Minchat Chinukh is a commentary on Sefer HaChinukh. Minchat Chinukh discusses the halakhic aspects of the mitzvot through the lens of the Talmud and the Rishonim.

A collection of correspondence related to the author's campaign against the study of philosophy, with a lengthy introduction concerning principles of faith. The book was published in 1838 in Pressburg, with an approbation from the leading authority at the time, R' Moshe Sofer (Chatam Sofer).
column4: אוסף התכתבות בענין המלחמה שניהל המחבר נגד לימוד הפילוסופיה, עם הקדמה ארוכה המבאר עיקרי האמונה ויסודות התורה. הספר נדפס בפרשבורג ב-1838 עם הסכמה מה"חתם סופר".

column1: Mishneh Torah, Things Forbidden on the Altar
column3: The eighth book is Avodah (Divine Service): the laws of the Temple in Jerusalem. Hilchot Issurei Hamizbeah: Laws of (entities) prohibited to be offered on the altar

Classic work containing the teachings of the great Hasidic master, Rebbe Elimelech of Lizhensk. The book, which contains many key aspects of Hasidic ideology, was not authored by him directly, but is rather based on written recordings of his lectures by his students. These were compiled by his son Elazar and published a year after his passing, at the request of his father, who did not want them released in his lifetime for "undisclosed reasons". (The book has asterisks or stars placed in seemingly random places within the text. Tradition has it that these stars were placed by the author intentionally and contain some meaning. They are therefore included in almost all printed editions of the work.)
column4: אחד מספרי היסוד של תנועת החסידות, המכיל שיחות דרשות ועיונים על פרשיות השבוע מהרבי אלימלך מליזענסק. גם נכלל בו חומר רב המפרט את האידאולוגיה ואת דרך החיים של החסידות. רבי אלימלך מדגיש במיוחד בספרו את מושג ה"צדיק" ועל כן יש שכינוהו "ספרן של צדיקים". הספר לא נכתב על ידו, אלא נלקט מרשימות של התלמידים ונדפס על ידי בנו, אלעזר, שכותב בהקדמתו שקיבל רשות מאביו להדפיסם - אך רק אחרי מותו, "מטעם כמוס". (בספר יש כוכביות או כוכבים שהוצבו במקומות אקראיים לכאורה בטקסט. לפי המסורה יש לכוכבים אלה איזה משמעות כלשהי, ולכן הם כלולים כמעט בכל המהדורות המודפסות של הספר.)

column3: One of the classic books of responsa of the last several hundred years.
One of the classic books of responsa of the last several hundred years.
A book of chassidic essays according to the weekly parsha, it became a classic of chassidut.
An introduction to the study of Kabbalah and its importance.
column4: ספרו של הרמ"ק העוסק במעלת לימוד הקבלה וחשיבותו.

column3: Commentary on Torah by Chida.
column4: פירושים והערות על התורה כסדר הפרשיות מהחיד"א.

column3: The order of the readings at the Passover Seder according to the Sephardi tradition.
Teachings of Isaac Luria (Arizal), recorded by his student Hayyim Vital.
column4: אחד מספרי כתבי האר"י, נכתב על ידי תלמידו, ר' חיים ויטאל.

column1: Pri Yitzhak on Sefer Yetzirah Gra Version

column3: Commentary on Sefer Yetzirah mistakenly attributed to Raavad, ascribed by Moses Kordovero and Chida to Yosef ben Shlomo Ashkenazi, an early 14th century Kabbalist.
column4: פירוש על ספר יצירה מיוחס להראב"ד, אך המחבר האמיתי (המזוהה על ידי רמ"ק וחיד"א) הוא המקובל ר' יוסף בן שלום אשכנזי.

column3: A commentary written by Rabbi Levi ben Gershon (1288–1344) of Provence. Ralbag was a Talmudist, mathematician and astronomer. He was a rationalist which is reflected in his approach to angels and miracles in his commentary. The commentary is divided into 3 parts: the lexicon (bi’ur ha-milot), exegesis (bi’ur ha-parasha), and the lessons (to’alot).

A commentary written by Rabbi Levi ben Gershon (1288–1344) of Provence. Ralbag was a Talmudist, mathematician and astronomer. He was a rationalist which is reflected in his approach to angels and miracles in his commentary. The commentary is divided into 3 parts: the lexicon (bi’ur ha-milot), exegesis (bi’ur ha-parasha), and the lessons (to’alot).

A commentary written by Rabbi Levi ben Gershon (1288–1344) of Provence. Ralbag was a Talmudist, mathematician and astronomer. He was a rationalist which is reflected in his approach to angels and miracles in his commentary. The commentary is divided into 3 parts: the lexicon (bi’ur ha-milot), exegesis (bi’ur ha-parasha), and the lessons (to’alot).
Commentary on Sefer Yetzirah attributed to Ramban. (See the introduction of R' C.D. Chavell in Kitvei Ramban Vol. 2 Pg. 451).
column4: פירוש לספר יצירה המיוחס להרמב"ן. (ראה המבוא של ר' חיים דוד שעוועל בכתבי הרמב"ן חלק ב עמוד תנא).

column3: Commentary written by Saadia Gaon (Babylonia, 882-942).

Hilchot HaRif or Sefer HaHalachot, written by Isaac ben Jacob Alfasi ha-Cohen (1013–1103) compiles the legal decisions from the tractates of the Talmud relating to halakha that was practiced in his day. The Rif recorded the halakhic rulings without the discussions surrounding them. He also excluded all non-halakhic material. The Rif became the basis of many later works.
column4: הלכות הריף או "ספר ההלכות", שנכתב על ידי יצחק בן יעקב אלפסי הכהן (1013-1103), מסכם את ההכרעות הנוגעות להלכה במסכתות התלמוד ללא הדיונים ומשא ומתן הארוך.

column3: Hilchot HaRif or Sefer HaHalachot, written by Isaac ben Jacob Alfasi ha-Cohen (1013–1103) compiles the legal decisions from the tractates of the Talmud relating to halakha that was practiced in his day. column3: Concise commentary on the Talmud, written by Rabbi Yom Tov ben Avraham Isbilli (Ritva). The author was a Spanish, medieval rabbi and halakhic authority. His commentaries to many tractates of the Talmud are a mainstay of yeshiva study to this day.
column4: פירוש על הש"ס לאחד מגדולי הראשונים, רבינו יום טוב בן אברהם אשבילי, הנחשב לאחד מהפירושים היסודיים לתלמוד שנלמדים בישיבות עד היום.

column3: Concise commentary on the Talmud, written by Rabbi Yom Tov ben Avraham Isbilli (Ritva). The author was a Spanish, medieval rabbi and halakhic authority. His commentaries to many tractates of the Talmud are a mainstay of yeshiva study to this day.

column1: Second Version of Ibn Ezra on Esther

column3: Monumental Torah commentary by R' Yehuda Leib Alter of Gur, considered one of the pillars of Chassidic thought. The title of the book is based on his last discourse, which ended with a verse from Mishlei (12,19): "Sefat Emet Tikon La'ad" — The lips of truth shall be established forever.
column4: מאמרים על סדר פרשיות התורה מהרב יהודה לייב אלתר, האדמו"ר מגור, הנחשב לאחד מספרי היסוד בתחום המחשבה החסידי. הכותרת של הספר מבוסס על המאמר האחרון שכתב, המסתיים עם המילים של הפסוק (משלי יב, יט) 'שפת אמת תיכון לעד'.

column3: Anonymous Kabbalistic work containing a lengthy commentary on the 613 commandments. It was ascribed by some to the 2nd century Tanna, R' Nehunya ben HaKanah, but it has been proven to be of much later authorship.
column4: טעמי תרי"ג המצוות בדרך הקבלה. יש המייחסים אותו להתנא ר' נחוניא בן הקנה, אך החיד"א פקפק בכך מכיון שמוזכר בהספר גם שמות של אמוראים.

column3: A short text summarizing all of the commandments, also known as the Azharot. This text was explained much later in great detail by Rabbi Yerucham Fishel Perlow.
A book explaining the principles of Hebrew grammar, which was translated into Latin by one of the great Christian Hebraists of the time under Bachur's supervision.

Sha'are Orah, or Sefer ha-Orah, (‎שערי אורה‎) is Gikatilla's most influential work. It discusses 300 ‎names of God and organized into ten chapters, one for each sephirah. Each sephirah has one main ‎name, but may have many others. Some names are associated with more than one sephirah. The ‎Arizal call it "a key to understanding the mystical studies". The Vilna Gaon and Zundel Salant ‎recommended that their students study it.‎
A classic of yeshiva study, in which the author deals at length with some of the most complicated and yet central topics in the Talmud.

A collection of eight notebooks containing the writings of Rav Kook covering a variety of subjects, on which the books of his teachings authored by his son and students were based. These writings were published in unedited form in 1999.
column4: שמונה פנקסים המכילים כתביו של הרב קוק משנים תרס"ד-תרע"ט. מתוך כתבי יד אלו ליקטו וערכו בנו הרב צבי יהודה ותלמידו הרב דוד כהן את ספרי האורות. הפנקסים נדפסו בשנת 1999 בצורתם המקורי (בלי עיבוד).

column3: Responsa that were transmitted from the Heavenly Academy to questions that were submitted by means of an 'inquiry of dreams'.
column4: תשובות מבית דין של מעלה לשאלות שנשאלו על ידי שאלת חלום.

column3: Translation and commentary on the Torah by Saadia Gaon. ("Tafsir" is an Arabic term meaning 'Biblical commentary'). Although we have it in Judeo-Arabic form, Ibn Ezra seems to indicate that it was originally written in Arabic letters as well.

Targum Jonathan is an Aramaic translation of the Neviim (Prophets). Authorship of the Targum is attributed to Jonathan ben Uzziel, a student of Hillel. In Talmudic times, the Targum was read verse-by-verse, alternating with the Hebrew text of the haftarah.

Apparently the latest of the Targumim, the Targum of Chronicles is filled in with many midrashic interpretations.
Apparently the latest of the Targumim, the Targum of Chronicles is filled in with many midrashic interpretations.

column1: Tosafot Yom Tov Introduction to the Mishnah
column3: Commentary on the Mishnah written by Rabbi Yom-Tov Lipmann Heller (1579 - 1654). Tosafot Yom Tov has become a standard commentary on the Mishnah and complements the Bartenura commentary.The release and digitization of this work was kindly sponsored by Nicole and Raanan Agus.
column4: פירוש המשנה לר' יום טוב ליפמן הלר, המהווה כעין השלמה לפירוש הברטנורא. הוא נדפס, (או קיצורו הנקרא "עיקר תוספות יום טוב"), ברוב המהדורות של המשנה ליד פירושו של ברטנורא.

column3: Written by Rabbi Israel Lipschitz (1782–1860), Tiferes Yisrael, often referred to as Mishnayos Yachin uBoaz is a commentary on the Mishnah. The commentary is divided into two parts; Yachin and Boaz. Yachin is the plain-sense explanation of the text, and Boaz contains lengthier analytical insights. Appended to each chapter is a section called "Hilchata Gevirta" containing a Halachic synopsis of each mishna. Many tractates are also preceded with an introduction and a separate essay discussing the subject matter at length.
column4: פירוש המשנה לרב ישראל ליפשיץ, נקרא גם "יכין ובועז" על שם שהוא נחלק לשני חלקים: "יכין" הוא ביאור פשט הפשוט של המשנה, ו"בועז" הוא חלק החידושים. בסוף כל פרק יש "הלכתא גבירתא" שהוא סיכום הלכתי של כל משנה. גם הוסיף הקדמות לכל הסדרים, ולהרבה מסכתות יש מאמר ארוך העוסק בענינים הנדונים בהם.

Appended to each chapter is a section called "Hilchata Gevirta" containing a Halachic synopsis of each mishna. Many tractates are also preceded with an introduction and a separate essay discussing the subject matter at length.
column4: פירוש המשנה לרב ישראל ליפשיץ, נקרא גם "יכין ובועז" על שם שהוא נחלק לשני חלקים: "יכין" הוא ביאור פשט הפשוט של המשנה, ו"בועז" הוא חלק החידושים. בסוף כל פרק יש "הלכתא גבירתא" שהוא סיכום הלכתי של כל משנה. גם הוסיף הקדמות לכל הסדרים, ולהרבה מסכתות יש מאמר ארוך העוסק בענינים הנדונים בהם.

column4: השמטות מספר "עבודת ישראל" להמגיד מקוזניץ, כולל בתוכו חידושים על התורה ושולחן ערוך.

column3: One of the most complex and penetrating of the Hasidic classics. Authored by the Maggid of Kozhnitz, it draws heavily on his Kabbalistic knowledge.

column3: The first dictionary of Biblical vocabulary composed in Hebrew.

column3: A discussion of the time period and identity of the author of Sefer HaZohar.

Commentary on the minor tractates of the Talmud, written by Rabbi Jacob Naumberg (Germany, d. 1811). Nahalat Yaakov is printed in the Vilna edition of the Talmud.
Commentary on the minor tractates of the Talmud, written by Rabbi Jacob Naumberg (Germany, d. 1811). Nahalat Yaakov is printed in the Vilna edition of the Talmud.

A version of this minor tractate dealing with converts found in manuscript form by Rabbi Hayyim Yosef David Azoulay and subsequently published by him, after he had published a less correct version almost twenty years earlier.

column1: Nuschaot from Manuscripts on Tractate Soferim

column3: Rabbi Moshe ben Maimon’s (Rambam) commentary was the first to be written on the entire Mishnah. The commentary was written by Rambam in Judeo-Arabic, and has been translated into Hebrew. He started working on it at age 23 while living in Spain, and completed it seven years later after settling in Egypt. It offers a running commentary on the Mishnah, and often includes a Halachic ruling based on the Talmud's conclusion.
column4: פירושו של הרמב"ם הוא הראשון שנכתב על כל המשנה, והוא אחד הפירושים החשובים שעל המשנה. הרמב"ם כתבו בצעירותו בשפה הערבית-יהודית, ותורגם פעמים רבות לעברית. הפירוש מכיל ביאור קצר לכל משנה ודיון מעמיק בעניינים המרכזיים שבה. בסוף כל עניין הוא פוסק הלכה על-פי מסקנת התלמוד.
column7: Spain; Fes, Morocco; Acre, Israel; Fustat, Egypt

column4: פירושו של הרמב"ם הוא הראשון שנכתב על כל המשנה, והוא אחד הפירושים החשובים שעל המשנה. הרמב"ם כתבו בצעירותו בשפה הערבית-יהודית, ותורגם פעמים רבות לעברית. הפירוש מכיל ביאור קצר לכל משנה ודיון מעמיק בעניינים המרכזיים שבה. בסוף כל עניין הוא פוסק הלכה על-פי מסקנת התלמוד.
column7: Spain; Fes, Morocco; Acre, Israel; Fustat, Egypt

column3: Essays on the Torah by Rabbi Francis Nataf. Rabbi Nataf incorporates a wide variety of midrashim and commentaries with his careful analysis of the text to provide the reader with innovative ways to look at well known episodes from the Torah.

Concise commentary on the Talmud, written by Rabbi Yom Tov ben Avraham Isbilli (Ritva). The author was a Spanish, medieval rabbi and halakhic authority. His commentaries to many tractates of the Talmud are a mainstay of yeshiva study to this day.
column4: פירוש על הש"ס לאחד מגדולי הראשונים, רבינו יום טוב בן אברהם אשבילי, הנחשב לאחד מהפירושים היסודיים לתלמוד שנלמדים בישיבות עד היום.

column3: Concise commentary on the Talmud, written by Rabbi Yom Tov ben Avraham Isbilli (Ritva). The author was a Spanish, medieval rabbi and halakhic authority. His commentaries to many tractates of the Talmud are a mainstay of yeshiva study to this day.
column4: פירוש על הש"ס לאחד מגדולי הראשונים, רבינו יום טוב בן אברהם אשבילי, הנחשב לאחד מהפירושים היסודיים לתלמוד שנלמדים בישיבות עד היום.

column3: Important religious-philosophical work by Joseph Albo, Sefer HaIkkarim ("Book of Principles") elaborates on aspects of Jewish faith. In contrast to Maimonides who bases religious belief on thirteen principles, Albo narrows them down to three main roots: a) G-ds existence; b) Divine origin of Torah; c) Divine reward and punishment. These three are then divided further into secondary roots ("shorashim"). His omission of the belief in the Messiah drew criticism from Abarbanel and others.
column4: ספרו של רבי יוסף אלבו בנושא עיקרי האמונה היהודית. בניגוד להרמב"ם שמנה י"ג עקרים, אלבו צמצם אותם, ולדעתו הם שלשה: מציאות השם, תורה מן השמיים, ושכר ועונש. מן העיקרים האלו נובעים מה שהוא קורא "שורשים" המסתעפים מהם. הימנעותו מלכלול את האמונה בביאת המשיח כעיקר עוררה עליו ביקורת מהאברבנאל ואחרים.

column3: The minor tractates (Masekhtot Ketanot) are essays from the Tannaitic period or later dealing with topics about which no formal tractate exists in the Mishnah. The first eight or so contain much original material; the last seven or so are collections of material scattered throughout the Talmud. Soferim (Scribes). This tractate deals with issues relating to slaves.

The minor tractates (Masekhtot Ketanot) are essays from the Tannaitic period or later dealing with topics about which no formal tractate exists in the Mishnah. The first eight or so contain much original material; the last seven or so are collections of material scattered throughout the Talmud. Soferim (Scribes). This tractate deals with issues relating to the requirements for accepting converts.

The minor tractates (Masekhtot Ketanot) are essays from the Tannaitic period or later dealing with topics about which no formal tractate exists in the Mishnah. The first eight or so contain much original material; the last seven or so are collections of material scattered throughout the Talmud. Soferim (Scribes). This tractate deals with issues relating to a mezuzah.

The minor tractates (Masekhtot Ketanot) are essays from the Tannaitic period or later dealing with topics about which no formal tractate exists in the Mishnah. The first eight or so contain much original material; the last seven or so are collections of material scattered throughout the Talmud. Soferim (Scribes). This tractate deals with issues relating to the writing of a Torah scroll.

The minor tractates (Masekhtot Ketanot) are essays from the Tannaitic period or later dealing with topics about which no formal tractate exists in the Mishnah. The first eight or so contain much original material; the last seven or so are collections of material scattered throughout the Talmud. Soferim (Scribes). This tractate appears in two different versions in the Jerusalem and Babylonian Talmuds.

The minor tractates (Masekhtot Ketanot) are essays from the Tannaitic period or later dealing with topics about which no formal tractate exists in the Mishnah. The first eight or so contain much original material; the last seven or so are collections of material scattered throughout the Talmud. Soferim (Scribes). This tractate deals with issues relating to tefillin.

The minor tractates (Masekhtot Ketanot) are essays from the Tannaitic period or later dealing with topics about which no formal tractate exists in the Mishnah. The first eight or so contain much original material; the last seven or so are collections of material scattered throughout the Talmud. Soferim (Scribes). This tractate deals with issues relating to the wearing of tzitzit.

Tur HaAroch, a commentary on the Torah, is written by R’ Jacob ben Asher (c. 1269 - c. 1343), known as Ba’al haTurim. While his concise introductory "Parperaot" (lit. appetizers) gained wide popularity and is printed in most standard Chumashim, his commentary body is less known. The English translation is by Rabbi Eliyahu Munk.
column4: הפירוש המלא על התורה מר' יעקב בעל הטורים. (הפירוש הנדפס בחומשים בשם "בעל הטורים" הוא רק ההקדמות לכל פרשה, בהם כתב המחבר "מעט פרפראות וגימטריאות וטעמי המסורות להמשיך הלב").

column3: The minor tractates (Masekhtot Ketanot) are essays from the Tannaitic period or later dealing with topics about which no formal tractate exists in the Mishnah. The first eight or so contain much original material; the last seven or so are collections of material scattered throughout the Talmud. Avot of Rabbi Natan (Fathers of Rabbi Nathan). The Schechter edition contains two different versions (version A has 41 chapters and version B has 48).

column1: Binyan Yehoshua on Avot D'Rabbi Natan

column3: Ritual order of Grace after the meal, its recitation is mandated by the Torah for someone who eats bread.

An apocryphal book containing a Biblical history from the time of the creation until the Exodus. The book divides history into periods of 49 years, hence the title "Jubilees", and challenges accepted Jewish tradition by advocating following a solar calendar rather than the lunar cycle, which makes almost all Jewish holidays fall on a Sunday.
column4: ספר אפוקריפי שמכיל היסטוריה תנ"כית מתקופת הבריאה ועד יציאת מצרים. הספר מחלק את ההיסטוריה לתקופות של 49 שנים, (ומכאן הכותרת "ספר היובלים"), ומנוגד למסורת היהודית בכך שהוא קובע לוח השנה לפי שנת החמה ולא למחזור הירח כפי שמקובל, מה שגורם שכמעט כל החגים היהודיים יפלו ביום ראשון.

column1: Gra's Nuschah on Avot D'Rabbi Natan
Gra's Nuschah on Tractate Derekh Eretz Rabbah
Haggahot R' Yeshaya Berlin on Avot D'Rabbi Natan
Haggahot R' Yeshaya Berlin on Tractate Derekh Eretz Rabbah
Haggahot Ya'avetz on Avot D'Rabbi Natan
Haggahot Ya'avetz on Tractate Derekh Eretz Rabbah
Haggahot and Marei Mekomot on Tractate Kallah Rabbati
Kisse Rahamim on Avot D'Rabbi Natan
Last Thesis on Hilchos Talmud Torah

column3: Written by R. Nathan Sternhartz of Nemirov (1780–1845), this voluminous work — "Collected Laws" — follows the order of topics in the Shulchan Aruch, explaining them in the light of Breslov teachings.

Popular Biblical commentary by Rabbi Meir Leibush ben Yehiel Michel Wisser (Malbim). A trademark of the Malbim’s commentary is his belief that there are no synonyms or repetition in the Tanakh. Each word represents a different idea or concept.
column4: פירוש פופולרי על תנ"ך של ר' מאיר לייבוש בן יחיאל מיכל ויסר (מלבי"ם). בפירושו לחומש הוא מביא את מדרשי ההלכה ודן בהם בהשוואה לפשט הפסוקים תוך דיוקים בדקדוק המקרא. המלבי"ם נודע בדרך ייחודית בפירושו למקרא, ולשיטתו אין שום חזרה וכפילות בפסוקים ('מילים נרדפות' כפי שכונה על ידי מפרשים אחרים), אלא כל מילה מייצגת מושג או רעיון אחר.

column3: Popular Biblical commentary by Rabbi Meir Leibush ben Yehiel Michel Wisser (Malbim). A trademark of the Malbim’s commentary is his belief that there are no synonyms or repetition in the Tanakh. Each word represents a different idea or concept.

column3: Minchat Shai is a Masoretic commentary by Jedidiah Solomon ben Abraham Norzi. It includes grammatical treatises on Tanakh, noting all variant readings scattered through Talmudic and Midrashic literature.
column4: פירוש לתנ"ך העוסק בעיקר בצורתן, ניקודן ומסורתן של תיבות ואותיות המקרא. מטרת הפירוש היא לברר וללבן את גרסאות המקרא ולקבוע את הנוסח הנכון, על פי מה שדנו בעניינים אלו בספרי התלמוד והמדרש.

column3: Minchat Shai is a Masoretic commentary by Jedidiah Solomon ben Abraham Norzi. It includes grammatical treatises on Tanakh, noting all variant readings scattered through Talmudic and Midrashic literature.

column1: Mitzpeh Etan on Avot D'Rabbi Natan
Nahalat Yaakov on Tractate Derekh Eretz Rabbah
column3: Commentary on the minor tractates of the Talmud, written by Rabbi Jacob Naumberg (Germany, d. 1811). Nahalat Yaakov is printed in the Vilna edition of the Talmud.
An explanation of the order of the various tractates in this Seder. As in his other introductions to different parts of the Mishnah, Rambam clarity and organization come through here as well.
column7: Spain; Fes, Morocco; Acre, Israel; Fustat, Egypt

column3: Rabbi Moshe ben Maimon’s (Rambam) commentary was the first to be written on the entire Mishnah. The commentary was written by Rambam in Judeo-Arabic, and has been translated into Hebrew. He started working on it at age 23 while living in Spain, and completed it seven years later after settling in Egypt. It offers a running commentary on the Mishnah, and often includes a Halachic ruling based on the Talmud's conclusion.
column7: Spain; Fes, Morocco; Acre, Israel; Fustat, Egypt

column3: A classic Talmud commentary written by Rashbam -  Rashi’s grandson and a major Tosafist. This short commentary on only one page of this tractate is found in the standard edition of the Talmud.

column1: Rishon Letzion on Avot D'Rabbi Natan

column3: An apocryphal rendition of the tradition about a heroic woman named Judith, the plot of which resembles that of the biblical Yael, who seduces and kills an enemy general.

Sifrei (Books) also known as Sifrei debe Rav or Sifrei Rabbah refers to either of two works of Midrash halakhah, based on the biblical books of Bemidbar (Numbers) and Devarim (Deuteronomy). The earliest Sifrei is found in Talmudic times and successively cited by Geonim and Rishonim. This early version is certainly not identical with the modern Sifrei. The modern Sifrei is not a uniform work, but one composed of two parts, one on Numbers and one on Deuteronomy that were joined together. The Sifrei to Numbers is evidently a midrash which originated in R. Ishmael's school, and which has all the peculiarities and characteristics of such a work though this does not exclude borrowing form Mekhilta de R. Shimon. The Sifrei to Deuteronomy is of an entirely different nature. The main portion (Nos. 53-303), halakhic in character, is preceded and followed by haggadic parts, and it has all the characteristics of a midrash from the school of R. Akiba. Several anonymous passages may be cited to express the views of R. Simeon; this midrash may with a fair degree of certainty be ascribed to him. The editor certainly drew upon other midrashic works besides R. Simeon's midrash, especially upon that of R. Ishmael.
An apocryphal addition to the Book of Daniel.
column4: הוספה אפוקריפי לספר דניאל.

column3: A group of ten psalms arranged by Rebbe Nahman to atone for sins and especially for wasted seed.

The minor tractates (Masekhtot Ketanot) are essays from the Tannaitic period or later dealing with topics about which no formal tractate exists in the Mishnah. The first eight or so contain much original material; the last seven or so are collections of material scattered throughout the Talmud. Soferim (Scribes). This tractate deals with proper behavior.

The minor tractates (Masekhtot Ketanot) are essays from the Tannaitic period or later dealing with topics about which no formal tractate exists in the Mishnah. The first eight or so contain much original material; the last seven or so are collections of material scattered throughout the Talmud. Soferim (Scribes). This tractate deals with issues of marriage.

Thesis by the Grand Rabbi Gershon Henoch Leiner, the Radziner Rebbe (known as "Baal Hat'chelet"), concluding that Sepia officinalis (common cuttlefish) meets many of the criteria of t'chelet. English translation by Menachem Kalish and David Herzberg.
column4: מאמר מאת הרב גרשון חנוך ליינר, האדמו"ר מראדזין (המכונה "בעל התכלת"), המסכם כי "דיונון הרוקחים" (שם מדעי: Sepia officinalis) עונה על קריטריונים רבים של התכלת למצוות ציצית.

column1: Tumat Yesharim on Avot D'Rabbi Natan

column3: Ibn Ezra's philosophical work explaining the reasons for and the division of the biblical commandments. He also discusses the importance of acquiring a broad knowledge in secular subjects, such as science and grammar, in order to facilitate Torah study.
column4: ספרו של האבן עזרא העוסק במנין וטעמי המצוות. גם דובר בו על החשיבות של רכישת ידע נרחב בחכמות, כגון מדע ודקדוק, להבנת לימוד תורה.

column3: A popular compilation of customs and commentary on the synagogue liturgy through a halakhic lens by Rabbi David Abudarham (Spain, 14th century).
column4: נקרא במקורו "חיבור על פירוש הברכות והתפילות", אבל נודע בשם מחברו "אבודרהם". כולל פירוש ומנהגים על סדר התפילה.

column3: Supercommentary to Ibn Ezra's Torah commentary, included in many editions of Mikraot Gedolot.
column4: ביאור לפירושו של האבן עזרא לחומש, נדפס ברוב המהדורות של מקראות גדולות.

column3: R' Israel Meir Kagan's ("Hafetz Chaim") Biur Halacha - "Explanation of the Law" - is a commentary tangential to the Mishnah Berurah, providing complex analysis of the legal rulings of earlier halachic authorities

Written by Rabbi Shmuel Eliezer Edels, the Maharsha (1555 – 1631, Poland), Chidushei Aggadot is a commentary on the aggadic (non-legal) portions of the Talmud. The commentary reflects the author’s vast knowledge of philosophy and Kabbalah.
column4: פירוש על כל האגדות שבתלמוד בבלי.

column3: Commentary on the Talmud written by Rabbi Shmuel Eliezer Edels (Maharsha). Maharsha was an important halakhic authority in Poland (1555 – 1631). His commentary elucidates comments of Rashi and the Tosefists.
column4: פירוש על חלק ההלכה של גמרא, רש"י, ותוספות שבתלמוד בבלי.

column3: Commentary on the Talmud written by Rabbi Shmuel Eliezer Edels (Maharsha). Maharsha was an important halakhic authority in Poland (1555 – 1631). His commentary elucidates comments of Rashi and the Tosefists.
column4: פירוש על חלק ההלכה של גמרא, רש"י, ותוספות שבתלמוד בבלי.

column3: Glosses on the Talmud by Rabbi Shlomo Luria (Maharshal). An important component of the commentary is establishing the correct text of the Talmud. Maharshal scrutinized the published editions of the Talmud as well as the commentaries of Rashi, Tosafot, and other Rishonim. An abridged version of Chochmat Shlomo appears in nearly all editions of the Talmud today, together with the commentary of Maharsha.

An abridged version of Chochmat Shlomo appears in nearly all editions of the Talmud today, together with the commentary of Maharsha.

column3: Psalm 151 discusses the slaying of Goliath and is attributed to King David. However, it does not appear in the Masoretic text and appears to be a much later composition.

column3: Commentary on the Talmud written by the Rashba, Rabbi Shlomo ben Avraham ibn Aderet (1235–1310). Rashba was a student of Ramban and follows his methodology. Rashba’s commentary is characterized by the depth of analysis and his search for the pshat (contextual meaning) of the text. Rashba’s commentary includes definitive legal rulings.

Concise commentary on the Talmud, written by Rabbi Yom Tov ben Avraham Isbilli (Ritva). The author was a Spanish, medieval rabbi and halakhic authority. His commentaries to many tractates of the Talmud are a mainstay of yeshiva study to this day.
column4: פירוש על הש"ס לאחד מגדולי הראשונים, רבינו יום טוב בן אברהם אשבילי, הנחשב לאחד מהפירושים היסודיים לתלמוד שנלמדים בישיבות עד היום.

column3: The minor tractates (Masekhtot Ketanot) are essays from the Tannaitic period or later dealing with topics about which no formal tractate exists in the Mishnah. The first eight or so contain much original material; the last seven or so are collections of material scattered throughout the Talmud. Soferim (Scribes). This tractate deals with proper behavior.

The minor tractates (Masekhtot Ketanot) are essays from the Tannaitic period or later dealing with topics about which no formal tractate exists in the Mishnah. The first eight or so contain much original material; the last seven or so are collections of material scattered throughout the Talmud. Soferim (Scribes). This tractate, it deals with issues of marriage.

Prominent liturgical poem (piyut) recited on the Jewish holiday of Shavuot by Ashkenazi Jews. Written in Aramaic by Rabbi Meir bar Yitzchak (Nehorai) of Orléans, who was a cantor (prayer leader) in Worms, Germany, (died ca. 1095). Akdamut consists of praise for God, His Torah, and His people.
column4: פיוט בשפה הארמית המדבר בשבחם של הקדוש ברוך הוא, עם ישראל, והתורה. אומרים אותו בקהילות אשכנז בחג השבועות לפני קריאת התורה.

column3: Also known as "Torat Moshe"; this Torah commentary was authored by Rabbi Moshe Alshich, a prominent 16th-century rabbi, in Safed, Ottoman Palestine. The Alshich was a popular preacher who gave lengthy lectures on the weekly Torah reading. These lectures were later published, in the form of a commentary, to ensure that they were repeated accurately and attributed to him. His style in Torat Moshe is to raise a number of questions and difficulties on a verse and then answer them all together by offering a new insight into the subject matter of the verse. His foremost aim in his commentary is to find fundamental moral and ethical lessons in the verses, or point out good qualities of character, such as faith, patience, humility, and so on.
column4: פירושו של ר' משה אלשיך (הנקרא "תורת משה"), מבוסס על דרשותיו. בהקדמה לפירושו על ספר דניאל הוא מסביר את דרך כתיבת פירושיו ומציין שפירושיו הם עיבוד של דרשות שנשא.

column3: In this volume, Rabbi Moshe Tendler, student and son-in-law of Rav Moshe Feinstein, translates more than a dozen of Rav Feinstein’s teshuvot. Among them are teshuvot on various aspects of the care of the terminally ill, on the question of “brain death,” and on the factor of “quality of life” as it affects the questions of employing extraordinary medical measures to maintain terminally ill patients on life support.  The release and digitization of this book was kindly sponsored by The Applebaum Foundation.
column4: תהליך הדיגיטציה של ספר זה והנגשתו בחסות קרן אפלבאום.

column3: Ibn Ezra’s commentary on the Tanakh reflects his knowledge as a Hebrew grammarian and philologist. His commentary is terse and aims to discover the pshat, the contextual meaning, of the text. Ibn Ezra was known for his independent ideas which aroused much controversy. Many view Ibn Ezra as the forefather of Biblical criticism. As an example, in the last chapter of Sefer Devarim (34:10), Ibn Ezra comments that Joshua, and not Moshe, wrote from this point until the end of the Torah.

column1: Lehem Mishneh on Mishneh Torah, Appraisals and Devoted Property
column3: Commentary on Rambam's Mishneh Torah, incorporated with most editions of Rambam. While writing his commentary, the author became aware that R' Joseph Karo had recently released his own commentary entitled "Kesef Mishneh", so he decided to omit any duplicate material and label his own work "Lechem Mishneh" as a complementary text.

column4: פירוש על משנה תורה להרמב"ם הנדפס ברוב המהדורות. תוך כדי כתיבת חיבורו על הרמב"ם, הגיע לידי המחבר חיבורו של ר' יוסף קארו, "כסף משנה", ולכן השמיט כל מה שנכפל בחיבור שלו וקרא שם ספרו "לחם משנה", שהוא מעין תוספת על "כסף משנה".

column1: Maggid Mishneh on Mishneh Torah, Borrowing and Deposit
column3: Written by Vidal of Tolosa, Maggid Mishneh is a commentary on Rambam’s Mishneh Torah. Although the original commentary covered the entire Mishneh Torah, only a portion is extant.

A commentary on the Talmud written by Rabbi Meir of Lublin (Maharam 1558 – 1616). Published after his death by his son, Gedaliah, in 1619, the commentary deals extensively with the interpretations of Rashi and the Tosafists.

Commentary on Chovot HaLevavot
column4: פירוש לספר חובות הלבבות

column3: Rabbi Shlomo Adani’s (1567–c.1630) Melekhet Shlomo commentary on the Mishnah. Authored at the same time as the renowned Tosafot Yom Tov, the Melekhet Shlomo remained in manuscript form for long after. It was first published in Vilna about two hundred and fifty years after the death of the author.
column4: פירוש על המשנה להרב שלמה עדני. על אף שנתחבר באותה תקופה של פירוש ה"תוספות יום טוב", הוא נשאר בכתב יד ולא נדפס עד כמאתים וחמישים שנה אחרי פטירת המחבר.

Authored at the same time as the renowned Tosafot Yom Tov, the Melekhet Shlomo remained in manuscript form for long after. It was first published in Vilna about two hundred and fifty years after the death of the author.
column4: פירוש על המשנה להרב שלמה עדני. על אף שנתחבר באותה תקופה של פירוש ה"תוספות יום טוב", הוא נשאר בכתב יד ולא נדפס עד כמאתים וחמישים שנה אחרי פטירת המחבר.

column3: Published by Salomon Buber, in 1885, based on material gathered from several manuscripts – this collection of aggadic midrashim is believed to be the oldest midrashic compilation of its kind.
column4: מדרש אגדה על פרשיות התורה הקדום והמקורי ביותר, נדפס על ידי שלמה בובר ב-1885

column3: Essays regarding the Egyptian exile and the Hebrew language.
column4: עיונים בענין גלות מצרים ומאמרים על לשון הקודש

column3: Commentary on Chovot HaLevavot
column4: פירוש על ספר חובות הלבבות

column1: Peirush on Mishneh Torah, Foundations of the Torah
column3: Commentary of unknown authorship on Hilchot Yesodei HaTorah in Rambam's Mishneh Torah.
column4: פירוש על הלכות יסודי התורה ב"משנה תורה" להרמב"ם ממחבר לא ידוע.

column3: Commentary of unknown authorship on Hilchot Teshuvah in Rambam's Mishneh Torah.
column4: פירוש על הלכות תשובה ב"משנה תורה" להרמב"ם ממחבר לא ידוע.

column3: Chassidic Torah commentary by Rabbi Menachem Mendel of Vitebsk, a principal disciple of the Maggid of Mezritch and head of the Chassidic pilgrimage to the Holy Land in 1777. The book also includes his letters encouraging and requesting financial support for the settlement of the Holy Land in general, and Tiberias in particular, as well as religious instruction and practice for the Chassidim who did not join his pilgrimage but remained behind in Europe.
column4: תורות ומאמרים של ר' מנחם מנדל מוויטעבסק, תלמיד המגיד ממעזריטש. הספר מכיל גם אגרות (שחלקם נכתבו על ידי תלמידו המובהק ויד ימינו, רבי אברהם מקאליסק) אשר נשלחו אל חסידיו במזרח אירופה. תוכנם של המכתבים כוללים דברי שבח וחיזוק חידוש ההתיישבות בארץ ישראל ובטבריה בפרט, בקשות לעזרה ולתמיכה כלכלית, וכן הוראות להחסידים שהשאיר מאחוריו בחוץ לארץ.

column3: Written by Gershon Henoch Leiner of Radzin (1839–1891), Ptil Tekhelet discusses the laws of the tekhelet, the blue dye used for the fringe of the tzitzit (tallit katan). The Rebbe made use of his knowledge in several scientific fields to discover the source of the tekhelet dye and promoted the use of tekhelet in tzitzit.

Essays on the Torah by Rabbi Francis Nataf. Rabbi Nataf incorporates a wide variety of midrashim and commentaries with his careful analysis of the text to provide the reader with innovative ways to look at well known episodes from the Torah.

Concise commentary on the Talmud, written by Rabbi Yom Tov ben Avraham Isbilli (Ritva). The author was a Spanish, medieval rabbi and halakhic authority. His commentaries to many tractates of the Talmud are a mainstay of yeshiva study to this day.
column4: פירוש על הש"ס לאחד מגדולי הראשונים, רבינו יום טוב בן אברהם אשבילי, הנחשב לאחד מהפירושים היסודיים לתלמוד שנלמדים בישיבות עד היום.

column3: Concise commentary on the Talmud, written by Rabbi Yom Tov ben Avraham Isbilli (Ritva). The author was a Spanish, medieval rabbi and halakhic authority. His commentaries to many tractates of the Talmud are a mainstay of yeshiva study to this day.
column4: פירוש על הש"ס לאחד מגדולי הראשונים, רבינו יום טוב בן אברהם אשבילי, הנחשב לאחד מהפירושים היסודיים לתלמוד שנלמדים בישיבות עד היום.

column3: Concise commentary on the Talmud, written by Rabbi Yom Tov ben Avraham Isbilli (Ritva). The author was a Spanish, medieval rabbi and halakhic authority. His commentaries to many tractates of the Talmud are a mainstay of yeshiva study to this day.
column4: פירוש על הש"ס לאחד מגדולי הראשונים, רבינו יום טוב בן אברהם אשבילי, הנחשב לאחד מהפירושים היסודיים לתלמוד שנלמדים בישיבות עד היום.

column3: Written by Rabbi Gershon Chanoch Henoch Leiner of Radzin as an introduction to his father's work – the "Beit Yaakov" – this work is a guide to the theology of Kabbalah and Chassidut, based on Talmudic, Halachic and esoteric sources.
column4: נכתב על ידי ר' גרשון חנוך העניך ליינר מראדזין כהקדמה ופתיחה לספרו של אביו, "בית יעקב".  בהספר מבואר עקרי ושרשי האמונה ויסודות הקבלה והחסידות.

column3: Comments on the status and role of angels and their rank vis-a-vis the nation of Israel, as described in the Talmud and Midrashim.
column4: ביאורים על עניינם ותפקידם של המלאכים, ומדרגתם לעומת ישראל, כפי שנמצא אודותם בתלמוד ובמדרשים.

column3: Comments regarding the existence and nature of supernatural beings, as reflected in the Talmud and Midrashim.
column4: ביאורים על קיומם וענינם של השדים, כפי שנמצא אודותם בתלמוד ובמדרשים.

column3: An allegorical commentary written by Philo (Alexandria; c. 20 BCE-45 CE) before the formulation of Tannaitic literature. These selected portions from Philo's Questions and Answers, and from his other writings, were translated into Hebrew from the Armenian and Greek, with a commentary based upon parallels from Rabbinic Literature, by Samuel Belkin.
column4: פרשנות אלגוריתית שכתב פילון מאלכסנדריה לפני כתיבת הספרות התנאית. ליקוטים מספר "שאלות ותשובות" ושאר כתבי פילון מתורגמים מארמנית ויוונית לעברית עם ביאורים והשוואות לספרות חז"ל, על ידי שמואל בלקין.

column3: Ibn Ezra’s response to a claim that a “day” of the Torah extends from dawn to dawn, rather than the traditional view of dusk to dusk. It is entitled "epistle" as the author writes that he received the contents of this work in the form of a letter from the Sabbath during a dream. (This edition is made available along with English translation and notes by Mordechai S. Goodman.)
column4: חיבור קטן מאבן עזרא, בו הוא מוכיח שיום השבת מתחיל מבערב, להוציא מדעת מי שטען שהלילה הולך אחר היום. כמו כן דן הספר בזמן תחילת החדש והשנה על פי תורה. המחבר כותב שהוא קיבל את תוכן הספר בדמות אגרת מהשבת בחלום הלילה.

column3: The first Chassidic work ever published, containing the teachings of the Baal Shem Tov as recorded by his senior disciple, Jacob Joseph of Polonne.
column4: ספר חסידות הראשון שראה אור הדפוס, מכיל את תורותיו של הבעל שם טוב כפי שנרשמו על ידי תלמידו הבכיר, יעקב יוסף כ"ץ מפולנאה. ספר זה נדפס ראשונה בקוריץ בשנת תק"מ, שנית במזיבוז בשנת תקע"ז, ואחר כך זכה להרבה מהדורות.

column3: Responsa of R' Nathaniel Weil, the author of Korban Netanel
column4: שו"ת מבעל קרבן נתנאל

column3: Talmud commentary of R' Yeshayah d'Trani, of which he composed as many as six editions to some tractates. The author displays stark originality and a quest for truth, as a result of which he often retracts a position he held in an earlier version, at times using a sharp manner of speech. He greatly revered Rashi, calling him "HaMoreh" (The Teacher), but does not hesitate to disagree with him on occasion.
column4: פירושו של ר' ישעיה ד'טראני למסכתות הש"ס, שעל הרבה מהם חיבר כמה מהדורות. בפירושיו הוא מצטיין במקוריותו ואהבת האמת שלו, ולפעמים הוא מבטל דבריו שכתב במהדורות קודמות בביטויים חריפים, כגון "מה שתירצתי שם הכל הבלים". למרות שהוא מגלה יראת הכבוד כלפי רש"י ומכנהו "המורה", הוא לא מהסס לחלוק עליו כשרואה לנכון.

column3: Talmud commentary of R' Yeshayah d'Trani, of which he composed as many as six editions to some tractates. column3: Talmud commentary of R' Yeshayah d'Trani, of which he composed as many as six editions to some tractates. The author displays stark originality and a quest for truth, as a result of which he often retracts a position he held in an earlier version, at times using a sharp manner of speech. He greatly revered Rashi, calling him "HaMoreh" (The Teacher), but does not hesitate to disagree with him on occasion.
column4: פירושו של ר' ישעיה ד'טראני למסכתות הש"ס, שעל הרבה מהם חיבר כמה מהדורות. בפירושיו הוא מצטיין במקוריותו ואהבת האמת שלו, ולפעמים הוא מבטל דבריו שכתב במהדורות קודמות בביטויים חריפים, כגון "מה שתירצתי שם הכל הבלים". למרות שהוא מגלה יראת הכבוד כלפי רש"י ומכנהו "המורה", הוא לא מהסס לחלוק עליו כשרואה לנכון.
