Written by Rabbi Shmuel Eliezer Edels, the Maharsha (1555 – 1631, Poland), Chidushei Aggadot is a commentary on the aggadic (non-legal) portions of the Talmud. The commentary reflects the author’s vast knowledge of philosophy and Kabbalah.
column4: פירוש על כל האגדות שבתלמוד בבלי.

column3: Written by Rabbi Shmuel Eliezer Edels, the Maharsha (1555 – 1631, Poland), Chidushei Aggadot is a commentary on the aggadic (non-legal) portions of the Talmud. The commentary reflects the author’s vast knowledge of philosophy and Kabbalah.
column4: פירוש על כל האגדות שבתלמוד בבלי.

column1: Commentary of the Rosh on Nazir
column3: Beyond his famous Halakhot summary found on most of the Talmud, Rosh (Rabbenu Asher ben Yechiel) also penned a concise commentary on certain tractates - meant to facilitate their study, and more in the style of Rashi than in that of Tosafot.

column1: Commentary of the Rosh on Nedarim
column3: Beyond his famous Halakhot summary found on most of the Talmud, Rosh (Rabbenu Asher ben Yechiel) also penned a concise commentary on certain tractates - meant to facilitate their study, and more in the style of Rashi than in that of Tosafot.

column1: Commentary of the Rosh on Tamid

This work is attributed to Maharal, but is believed to be of later authorship. While much of the material is taken from the Maharal's writings, some claim that the publisher, Rabbi Yudel Rosenberg, incorporated some of his own ideas into the text.
column4: פירוש על הגדה של פסח מיוחס למהר"ל מפראג, אבל יש הטוענים שהמוציא לאור, רב יודל רוזנברג, הוסיף בו דברים משלו.

column3: Ibn Ezra’s commentary on the Tanakh reflects his knowledge as a Hebrew grammarian and philologist. His commentary is terse and aims to discover the pshat, the contextual meaning, of the text. Ibn Ezra was known for his independent ideas which aroused much controversy. Many view Ibn Ezra as the forefather of Biblical criticism. As an example, in the last chapter of Sefer Devarim (34:10), Ibn Ezra comments that Joshua, and not Moshe, wrote from this point until the end of the Torah.

column1: Ibn Ezra on Song of Songs
column3: Ibn Ezra’s commentary on the Tanakh reflects his knowledge as a Hebrew grammarian and philologist. His commentary is terse and aims to discover the pshat, the contextual meaning, of the text. Ibn Ezra was known for his independent ideas which aroused much controversy. Many view Ibn Ezra as the forefather of Biblical criticism. As an example, in the last chapter of Sefer Devarim (34:10), Ibn Ezra comments that Joshua, and not Moshe, wrote from this point until the end of the Torah.
Prayers for various occasions, compiled by Chida.
column4: תפילות לזמנים ומצבים שונים, מלוקט על ידי ר' חיים יוסף דוד אזולאי (חיד"א).

column3: Laws of daily prayer, compiled by Chida.
column4: דיני תפילה מאת ר' חיים יוסף דוד אזולאי (חיד"א).

column3: Kabbalistic commentary on the Mishnah.
column4: פירוש למשנה על דרך הקבלה. שם הספר הוא גימטריה של שם המחבר ושם אמו.

column3: A commentary on the Talmud written by Rabbi Meir ben Jacob Ha-Kohen Schiff. Rabbi Schiff (1608 - c. 1644) wrote commentary on the entire Talmud although only a portion remains extant. A defining characteristic of Rabbi Schiff's commentary is his dislike of pilpul.

A commentary on the Talmud written by Rabbi Meir ben Jacob Ha-Kohen Schiff. Rabbi Schiff (1608 - c. 1644) wrote commentary on the entire Talmud although only a portion remains extant. A defining characteristic of Rabbi Schiff's commentary is his dislike of pilpul.

column1: פירוש פופולרי על תנ"ך של ר' מאיר לייבוש בן יחיאל מיכל ויסר (מלבי"ם). בפירושו לחומש הוא מביא את מדרשי ההלכה ודן בהם בהשוואה לפשט הפסוקים תוך דיוקים בדקדוק המקרא. המלבי"ם נודע בדרך ייחודית בפירושו למקרא, ולשיטתו אין שום חזרה וכפילות בפסוקים ('מילים נרדפות' כפי שכונה על ידי מפרשים אחרים), אלא כל מילה מייצגת מושג או רעיון אחר.
column3: Written by Rabbi Meir Leibush ben Yehiel Michel Wisser (Malbim), a trademark of the his commentary is his belief that there are no synonyms or repetition in the Tanakh. Each word represents a different idea or concept. Another important facet is his interest in connecting the written word to its rabbinic interpretation.

A classic German Haggadah that brings down many otherwise unknown insights and customs from the author's library and from his father, the author of Korban Netanel.
column12: מרבה לספר על הגדה של פסח

column3: Midrashic commentary on the Torah and Megilot. The title of the work alludes to the author's name, Toviah, in addition to his practice of introducing each portion in the Torah commentary with a short exposition on a verse containing the word 'Tov'.
column4: מדרש לקח טוב, המכונה גם פסיקתא זוטרתא, הוא פירוש מדרשי על חמשת חומשי תורה וחמש מגילות. שם הספר מרמז לשם המחבר, טוביה, וגם למנהגו להתחיל כל פרשה עם ביאור קצר על פסוק שיש בו המילה 'טוב'. הפתיחה לפרשת בראשית הוא פירוש על הפסוק 'כי לקח טוב נתתי לכם'.

column3: Minchat Shai is a Masoretic commentary by Jedidiah Solomon ben Abraham Norzi. It includes grammatical treatises on Tanakh, noting all variant readings scattered through Talmudic and Midrashic literature.
column4: פירוש לתנ"ך העוסק בעיקר בצורתן, ניקודן ומסורתן של תיבות ואותיות המקרא. מטרת הפירוש היא לברר וללבן את גרסאות המקרא ולקבוע את הנוסח הנכון, על פי מה שדנו בעניינים אלו בספרי התלמוד והמדרש.

column1: Notes and Corrections on Midrash Lekach Tov
column3: Scholarly notes, references and citation of textual variants from this careful scholar and editor of many volumes of the Midrash. The notes were published alongside the first printing of the first two volumes (on Genesis and Exodus) of this book of midrash.
Classic work of Talmudic novellae, widely studied to this day.
column4: חידושים וביאורים על מסכתות הש"ס. הספר הוא מאד פופולרי בעולם הישיבות, והוא נחשב לאחד מאבני היסוד במשא־ומתן התלמודי. בהקדמה לספרו כותב המחבר שהמניע לכתיבת הספר הייתה סיפור מעניין: ביום ג' בכסלו ה'תס"ג אירע רעידת אדמה בלבוב, שגרמה לפיצוץ מחסן חומר הנפץ בעיר. בעת ההוא ישב ולמד בביתו כשפתאום קרס עליו הבית. בשכבו תחת ההריסות הוא נדר לה' שאם יוציאו משם בשלום יעסוק כל חייו בלימוד התורה וגם ימשיך במה שהתחיל סבו, בעל ה"מגיני שלמה" – תירוץ כל קושיות בעלי התוספות על רש"י. מיד כשסיים את נדרו נפתח בפניו שביל בין העמודים שקרסו והוא יצא בריא ושלם.

column3: Classic work of Talmudic novellae, widely studied to this day.

column3: The commentary of one of the main leaders of the French school of Tosafists, Rabbi Yitzchak (known by his initials as RI) of Dampierre.

column1: Tosafot Rid on Avodah Zarah First Recension
column3: Talmud commentary of R' Yeshayah d'Trani, of which he composed as many as six editions to some tractates. The author displays stark originality and a quest for truth, as a result of which he often retracts a position he held in an earlier version, at times using a sharp manner of speech. He greatly revered Rashi, calling him "HaMoreh" (The Teacher), but does not hesitate to disagree with him on occasion.
column4: פירושו של ר' ישעיה ד'טראני למסכתות הש"ס, שעל הרבה מהם חיבר כמה מהדורות. בפירושיו הוא מצטיין במקוריותו ואהבת האמת שלו, ולפעמים הוא מבטל דבריו שכתב במהדורות קודמות בביטויים חריפים, כגון "מה שתירצתי שם הכל הבלים". למרות שהוא מגלה יראת הכבוד כלפי רש"י ומכנהו "המורה", הוא לא מהסס לחלוק עליו כשרואה לנכון.

Abarbanel's extensive commentary on the book of Isaiah, powerfully focusing on the messianic prophecies in light of the expulsion from Spain. Much of it is a polemic against Christianity and it was aimed at helping Jews retain their loyalty to Judaism amid the upheavals in their lives.

Novellae on the weekly Torah portion and haftarah by Rabbi Yosef Hayyim (Ben Ish Chai). This was his first work and it is named after his father.
Book of sermons by Rabbi Hayyim Joseph David Azulay.
A kabbalistic commentary on the Torah by Rabbi Avraham Azulay. Azulay was a student of Rabbi Chaim Vital and the great-grandfather of Rabbi Chaim Yosef David Azulay.

column1: Bein HaShitin on Halacha and Aggadah

column3: One of the major commentaries on the Aggadah in the Babylonian Talmud. It is one of Rabbi Yosef Hayyim (Ben Ish Chai)'s two works on aggadah, both of which offer analytic as well as kabbalistic interpretations of the Talmud's narrative sections.

A commentary on the medieval pietistic work of R. Yehudah Hachasid, Brit Olam is one of many works by Rabbi Hayyim Joseph David Azulay.
A compilation of many of the sermons of Rabbi Avraham Yehoshua Heschel of Krakow. Heschel was a famous rabbinic leader in 17th century Poland.

A commentary on the book of Daniel by Rabbi Moshe Alshikh. One of the great rabbis of the heyday of Kabbalah in Safed, he uses different modes of interpretation - including Kabbalah - in order to address various questions he poses on the text.
A contemporary commentary on the Torah by Rabbi Yehudah Herzl Henkin.
A contemporary commentary on the book of Jonah as it relates to the Yom Kippur service by Rabbis Chaim and Binyamin Jachter.
The second tome of Rabbi Hayyim Joseph David Azulay's encyclopedic work on Jewish topics.
Another one of Rabbi Hayyim Joseph David Azulay's encyclopedic works on Jewish topics.

One of the classic commentaries on Midrash and Aggadah, it is devoted to analysing the various midrashim in light of each other and earlier commentators and then attempt to find creative new solutions to the apparent contradictions in the sources.

column1: Etz Yosef on Shir HaShirim Rabbah
column3: One of the classic commentaries on Midrash and Aggadah, it is devoted to analysing the various midrashim in light of each other and earlier commentators and then attempt to find creative new solutions to the apparent contradictions in the sources.

A landmark essay of new Hebrew literature, that envisions the relationship of classical halacha and aggadah as a model for the contours of the emerging Jewish culture in Palestine. It is also a harsh critique of Bialik's contemporaries, whom he blamed for artificially divorcing art from ethics and action.
An systematic introduction to Kabbalah, characteristic of the author's style in all of his works.
A Talmudic commentary which primarily dissects and explains the commentary of Rabbenu Asher (Rosh), it is printed together with that commentary in the standard version of the Talmud in use today.

column1: Levushei Serad on Shulchan Arukh, Orach Chayim
column3: An independent and insightful commentary on Shluchan Arukh, focusing primarily on the understandings of the Magen Avraham and Turei Zahav (Taz) commentaries.
The order of prayer and its various additions included in the traditional Ashkenazi Rosh Hashanah service.
The order of prayer and its various additions included in the traditional Ashkenazi Yom Kippur service.
Responsa from the son of the Or Zarua who, like his father, wrote extensively to many communities in response to questions of halakha that were referred to him.

A comprehensive guide and explanation of rabbinic interpretation of the Bible. In it, the author delves into the nuances of Hebrew vocabulary and grammar to determine 613 principles through which the Bible is to be interpreted.
The last books printed during this prolific author's lifetime, it is a commentary on the aggadic sections of the Talmud, basing itself largely on letter schemes and kabbalistic teachings.

An encyclopedic-style collection of concepts and statements from earlier writers in alphabetical order, explained and developed further by the author.
A frequently Hebraicized compilation of midrash, accompanied by interpretations and legal teachings of the author.
A commentary on the Torah, interpreting and expanding on the classic Targum Onkelos.
A classic made up of ethical maxims, divided into seventeen behavioral categories, such as faith, love, stinginess, etc.
A commentary on the Torah focused on finding meaning in the text from letter schemes, as well as from rabbinic and kabbalistic teachings.
A commentary on the weekly haftara sections of the Bible, focused on finding meaning in the text from letter schemes, as well as from rabbinic and kabbalistic teachings.
A comprehensive commentary of Pirkei Avot, setting up queries on the text of the Mishnah and subsequently resolving them, keeping with Abarbanel's style in his other commentaries.

A thorough work of halachic decisions, incorporating the talmudic sources as well as subsequent opinions. As opposed to many works of this type, the discussions are organized topically, and do not follow the order of the Talmud.
The first known commentary on Sefer Chasidim, it has been regularly attached to it since 1723/4
One of the few volumes of Raavad's commentaries on the Talmud to survive, it displays the author's critical independence, something he already reveals from his introductory comments.

A commentary on the book of Proverbs by Rabbi Moshe Alshikh. One of the great rabbis of the heyday of Kabbalah in Safed, he uses different modes of interpretation - including Kabbalah - in order to address various questions he poses on the text.

A commentary on the book of Proverbs by Rabbi Moshe Alshikh. One of the great rabbis of the heyday of Kabbalah in Safed, he uses different modes of interpretation - including Kabbalah - in order to address various questions he poses on the text.
Long essays using various verses and sections in the Torah as the point of departure for involved discussions often related to sections of the Talmud and the halachic discussions that come out of it.
A classic commentary on the Torah, analyzing the Biblical text, and using the Midrash and Talmud as the major resource from which to understand it.

Halachic compilation written by Rabbi Asher ben Yechiel, a German and Spanish halakhic authority (c. 1250 - 1327). Similar in style to Sefer HaHalachot of the Rif, Piskei HaRosh contains an abstract of the Talmudic text, leaving out the intermediate discussion and focusing on the final, practical halakha. Having been a leader in both Germany and Spain, the Rosh was familiar with the leading halakhic authorities of both countries and included teachings from both. The Rosh’s commentary displays his independence of judgement as he states his legal opinion according to what he views as most sound, even if it goes against other respected authorities. The importance of this work can be seen from the fact that it is one of the three major Halakhic sources that R' Yosef Karo consulted (along with Rif and Rambam) when determining the final ruling in his Shulchan Arukh.

A classic and the most important work of the medieval Chassidei Ashkenaz, it was written as a comprehensive guide to Jewish life. As such, it is a book of both ethical instruction and legal information. Given that the author was a pietist, he tends towards more stringent views in his legal opinions.
The Steinsaltz Edition of the Talmud is an interlinear translation and explanation of the text from the original Aramaic into modern Hebrew and English.
The Steinsaltz Edition of the Talmud is an interlinear translation and explanation of the text from the original Aramaic into modern Hebrew and English.
A three volume work of responsa and Talmudic commentary.
A introduction to kabbalistic thought.

A book of discourses on the parsha and on holidays, it is considered a chassidic classic. It is marked by its particular focus on the righteousness of Joseph and how he embodies the kabbalistic realm of yesod (foundation). The practical teaching that comes out of this is the importance of controlling one's desires.
A commentary explaining the simple and midrashic meaning of the text, most of the book's content can already be found in earlier works.

Largely a redaction of previous Tosafist glosses on the Talmud written earlier in France and Germany, it gave Spanish scholars access to that tradition for many centuries until other editions of Tosafot became more universally accessible.

Largely a redaction of previous Tosafist glosses on the Talmud written earlier in France and Germany, it gave Spanish scholars access to that tradition for many centuries, until other editions of Tosafot became more universally accessible.

An independent and critical commentary of the Talmud written in Tosafist style by one of the great medieval rabbis of Italy. It is marked not only by the author's often strong disagreement with earlier rabbis, but even by disagreement with earlier versions of his own work.
A commentary on the weekly haftarot sections of the Bible.

column1: A commentary on the classical commentators of the Shulchan Arukh.
column3: A commentary on the classical commentators of the Shulchan Arukh.
An important commentary on Pirkei Avot that was hailed by many rabbis as well worthy of study, for its profundity and ethical content, in spite of the ideological controversy surrounding its author.
A super-commentary on Rabbi Eliyahu Mizrachi's super-commentary on Rashi.

column1: A Jewish Critique of the Philosophy of Martin Buber
column3: An religous and philosophical critique of Buber and his influence by one of 20th century Orthodoxy's most eminent philosophers.

column3: Glosses on the Talmud by Rabbi Shlomo Luria (Maharshal). An important component of the commentary is establishing the correct text of the Talmud. Maharshal scrutinized the published editions of the Talmud as well as the commentaries of Rashi, Tosafot, and other Rishonim. An abridged version of Chochmat Shlomo appears in nearly all editions of the Talmud today, together with the commentary of Maharsha.

The topics are chosen for their general interest and importance, and each section concludes with a short decision by this experienced American posek that moves the discussion beyond just theory.

column3: A compilation of classical sources and relevant statements from earlier scholars, upon which the author builds to elaborate on the ideas in this one section of Mishneh Torah.

The first known compilation of halakha by category and not according to the order of the Talmud, it borrows heavily from the Sheiltot of Rav Ahai Gaon. Because it is a seminal work from the time of the Geonim, it is frequently mentioned in subsequent discussions of halakha. While there is much debate about its authorship, most believe it to be the work of Shimon Kayyara.

One of the classic commentaries on Midrash Rabbah, it has been printed in almost all editions of it for the last several hundred years. The author works to explain the words and meaning of the midrash according to its simple (peshat) understanding.

Classic 19th century commentary on Midrash Rabbah that analyzes midrash according to various patterns denoted by the author. In this way, the Midrash is presented as more rigorously attached to the verses of the Bible to which it serves as commentary.

Commentary on the Talmud written by the Rashba, Rabbi Shlomo ben Avraham ibn Aderet (1235–1310). Rashba was a student of Ramban and follows his methodology. Rashba’s commentary is characterized by the depth of analysis and his search for the pshat (contextual meaning) of the text. Rashba’s commentary includes definitive legal rulings. The text was found much later than the other volumes and there some who believe it was not written by Rashba.

Similar in style to Rashi's commentary on the Torah and on the Talmud, scholars believe this work was written by another scholar living around the same time as Rashi. Like Rashi, he aims to present a simple explanation for difficult words, phrases and concepts.

Using classical and innovative methodology, Hirsch was able to find many new understandings of various sections in the Torah. In particular, he is known for his ability to give strong contemporary relevance to the ancient narratives and laws, as well as for his creative theories about Hebrew word roots.

Recorded by one of Rabbi Soloveitchik's close students, Rabbi Hershel Reichman, these notes bring out Rabbi Soloveitchik's adept use of the "Brisker method" to identify conceptual categories that reveal a deeper possible meaning to otherwise contradictory texts.

column3: Biographies of many of the rabbis living in the Talmudic period, based primarily on Talmudic and midrashic sources.

column1: The Scientific and the Religious World View
column3: A sophisticated essay on the bases of scientific and religious approaches to knowledge and meaning, grounded in the philosophy of Kant.
An application of chassidic learning to various Talmudic texts related to the holidays and Parshat HaShavua.

column3: An essay about the centrality of Jewish unity and tolerance in traditional Jewish sources.

Originally initiated at the request of the Nazi regime in the 1930's, the author explains the nature and development of the Talmud in a sophisticated yet accessible manner. Disappointed that it did not show the Talmud's "true nature," the book was immediately burned by the authorities. The current translation from the German includes two chapters not published in the original due to fear of Nazi reaction.
A discussion about the nature and passion of faith against the backdrop of modern rationalism and faithlessness, of which the Holocaust is seen as a symptom.
An Enlightenment-era pamphlet advocating the teaching of secular studies in Jewish schools, based on classical Jewish teachings.

column3: A comprehensive commentary to the Haggadah written in typical Abarbanel style: He asks many insightful textual questions, reports possible answers from other commentators and finally relates his own original explanations.

An expansion on the teachings of his father, Rav Mordechai Yosef Leiner, the Izhbitzer Rebbe. These teachings - organized around the various Torah readings and festivals of the year - were collected by his own son and then published,.

A multi-volume set spanning much of Rav Uziel's career, his responsa contain many groundbreaking positions about Jewish life in the modern setting and in the new state of Israel, of which he was the first Sephardi chief rabbi.
A complete dictionary of all the Old French words and expressions used by Rashi in his commentaries on the Talmud and the Tanakh.
A voluminous and highly influential series of responsa written by a rabbi who dedicated himself to upholding Orthodoxy in the midst of emancipation and the Enlightenment.
